div.head: TO Sir John Hartop Baronet.
div.p:
THis little and unpolih'd Tract (by reaon of its Authors penive Thoughts, concerning its Entertainment among the Critic Cenurits of this Carping Age, and his careful Solicitude, to whoe Patronage he dare preume to commit it) is jut like a mall
Veel toed up and down in the midt of a turbulent Ocean, and buffered by the welling Waves of an unruly Element, having its Sails lacerated by the boiterous Aaults of an unmerciful Wind, and not knowing to what Port or Haven it had bet betake it elf: For when I eriouly reflect on my own Unworthines and Inufficiency, for a Work of this Nature, I am ahamed to think of expoing the Weaknes and Imperfection of my Juvenile Labours to Public View, much more when I contemplate on the Dignity and Grandure of your Peron, the multitude of your Natural and Acquired Accomplihments, the Profoundnes
of your Judgment, and the Accuracy of your Dicerning Faculty, am I Atoniht, and even tand Agat at the thoughts of appearing at the open Bar before o Dicerning a Judge. But yet on the other ide, when I conide you Candour and Clemency, the Natural Reult and Product of uch a Genuine Dipoition, as inclines you to Pardon and Overlook the common Frailties of Mankind; the Weight and Argument in this lat Conideration, to publih it, proeponderates that of the two former to keep it dormant: o that now having reolved to trike Anchor at the afe Harbour of your Name here prefixed, my fluctuating
Thoughts are already reduced to Calmnes and Serenity of Mind; and I value not the inconiderable Puffs and Blats of a thouand Cenurits but can Laugh at all their Taunts and Jeers, and Calumnies. Or hall I compare it to a Ship embarked with Goods (tho very ordinary) intended for a long Voyage, and fore-eeing a multitude of Storms and Tempets, which it mut unavoidably venter thro, yet having a Skilful and Succesful Pilot to teer its Coure, is not much concerned at thoe Perils, which otherwie would undoubtedly caue a Shipwrack?

Shall I alo compare it to an
Infant, which in the very Exit from the cloe Confinement of its Mothers Womb, and in the mid't of its Pangs, wants a Skilful Midwife to haten its Delivery. Thus Sir (to apply the Allegory) if this Partus, freed from the teeming Womb of its Authors Brain, wherein it was conceived and uhered Naked into the open World, doth but live, being Received and Embraced by uck as are Well-wihers to thoe good Intentions that begat it; it mut acknowledge its Life and Entertainment in the World, to be olely derived from you who would o Candidly Vouchafe to obtetricate it.

Therefore Worthy Sir, preuming upon your Benignity, I hall wholly devote it to your Patronage, and mut aure you, that tho it be not a purious Brat, yet I dare not acknowledge to be its Parent or own it to be my Legitime Off-pring, unles you will deign to make it yours Adopted.

And tho it may be rather called an Embrio than a perfect Partus, it being Fraught with many Imperfections, by reaon of its Parent's Infirmity, yet I hope the Conideration of this will rather excite you to Commierate it than caue you to Didain to Look on it; for certainly it
had ere this proved Abortive had it not continued to this (mall) Maturity, meerly being utained by the hopes of your Readines and Willingnes to render your Aid and Aitance in the extremity of its Exit, and in the neceitous time of this its Delivery.

Sir, It is not becaue I think any Benefit will accrue to you by your Inpection into this Dicoure, or that it will any way add to your Knowledge that I preent it to you, but knowing that you have a Genius which inclines you to uch Studies as thee, as well to more ublime ones, I cannot but hope that you will Encourage the ame, where you ee it in others, and by a kind Acceptance
and a candid Reentment of thee my Endeavours, manifet the ame.

Beides your willingly Patronizing omewhat of my Fathers (tho on another Subject) ome years ince, was a great inducement to make me hope and expect the ame unparell'd Favour from you; which humble Requet, if you will condecend to grant you will for ever oblige him who really is

div.head: THE EPITSLE TO THE READER.
div.p:
KNowledge was ever worried with the reproachful terms of Pride and Prophanes, by ome ignorant and blinded Zealots; And altho in thee clearer and brighter days, it has obtained many Choice and Pious Patrons, yet cannot that vindicate it from being lurred and
branded with the mot hameful and blemihing Titles; ome do o illy reent what favours of it, that one would imagine that they had a ecret Antipathy to it, lurking in the very frame of their Natures: Some damn it as Irreligious and Antichritian, and deem it wholly inconitent with Gopel Simplicity; becaue it ometimes dicovers the Darknes of that Light that they fancifully pretend to. Its wonderful to ee how many are continually puffing at this Light; ome with the more vehement blats of Rage anf Fury, others with the gentle ones of Scoff and Deriion, but each equally deigning its Final and Fatal Extinction. Revealed Knowledge, is to the Apprehenion of ome, a thing Dull and Irrational, Natural, with others is Sordid and Atheitic. Either of thoe Lights are much too Glorious for the vitiated Optics of uch Brutih Senualits. Nothing gratifies
them but what accords with their Humerous Dipoitions, and is tempered into a utablenes to their Corrupted Phancies: Its trange Men hould o much oppoe their own Happines, diown their clearet Faculties, and without the leat hadow of Provocation, be content to place themelves in a lower Rank than God and Nature has allowed them. To talk of the Immortality of the Humane Soul, to vindicate its Difference from Material Subtances, to aert its Divine Origin and Production, is now become ufficient to entitle a Peron to the Malignant Scoffs of ome Prophaner Wits: For Senuality is o much their Element, that they are not eaily perwaded to be Wie beyond it, neither can they be induced to think thoe things to have a proper Exitence, which are not capable of being confined to that Praedicament. So that what-ever is
declared of things Spiritual (things of a more Noble and Sublime Extraction than what's Corporeal) is by uch no otherwie eteemed than impertinent Babling. All that we hear from them of thee Matters, is only that contant Clamour, that to aert Immaterial, and Spiritual Beings is unintelligible Nonene. But it were unworthy any Peron of Ingenuity to be concerned, whenas the Purity of our Faculties, and a erious Reflection on their refined Nature, is Argument enough to convince any of the mot prodigious unreaonablenes of uch Frantic Surmies: Should we to gratifie ome pervere Humorit, reolve all our Knowledge into Sene, we mut be forced to confes that we undertood carcely any thing of our owu Natures; that we exerted Actions, which we could no more, nay les account for, than the Flux and Reflux of the Ocean;
and whoe Fountain and Original would be as undeterminable as that of Nibe, As for the reducing thoe Acts of Will and Undertanding, or thoe iner Reflex ones, to the Arietations and Fortuious Jumblings of inenible Atomes, is a Notion exceedingly gros and aburd: For the mot exquiite Motion of the moothet and mallet parts of Matter is utterly incompatible with the ubtle and refined Operations of a Spirits Faculties: So ridiculous does the Hypotheis of the Atheits eem to be, that I cannot imagine any hould adopt it, unles he were wayed by Interet, or byaed by ome ecret thoughts of his being capacitated to maintain any thing againt the mot violent Aaults of his well accomplihed Adveraries. Let the Atheitic Tribe brave it with never o much Confidence and Preumption, yet any Reaonable
Peron may at an eaie rate be informed of its groundlenes, and the Weaknes of its upport. Strong Confidence ought to be built on weighty Reaons and confirmed Truths, or the Supertructure will become the Object of Mens Scorn and Deriion: And whether the Confidence of ome Atheits be any better founded, I think the following Dicoure may in part evidence to any impartial and di-intereted Mind: I am perwaded that this piece will be acceptable to any to whom Knowledge is dear and delightful, but I judge it will be far otherwie to thoe that affect Ignorance, and Glory in their own Blindnes and Stupidity, that like the Negro's think nothing Beautiful but what dicovers it elf in their own Native Blacknes: But it were apparent Folly to manifet any Reentment of their Cenures, who endeavour
to leen the ditance between Man and Brutes, as is evidently viible by their earnet and vehement Attempts to caheir that Knowledge that makes the difference the more wide and conpicuous. The Subject, of the enuing Dicoure (as the Title Page aures us) is Man, the Compendium of the Univere, and a brief ummary of all Natures Works; o that indeed a Treatie on this Subject, is as it were a Commentary upon the whole Book of Nature: For that there is omething In Man Analogic to all the Parts of the Harmonious Structure of the World, is that which the Treatie in its very Entrance repreents by a very curious and exact Delenation: It decribes Man in almot all his Potures and Appearances, dicovers the Noble Extraction and Origin of his Diviner Part; clearly manifets the ublime Nature of the Properties and Faculties
of that Incorporeal Being; gives ome probable Conjectures of its Condition, both Antecedent and Conequent, to its tate of Union: Opens the Nature of the Affections, hews the Difference occaioned by the Terminations of the Iracible and Concupicible Appetites on the Variety of Objects. Then it evidences to us the Souls Immortality and detects the Vanity of Atheitic Cavils againt o famous and irrefragable a Truth: It alo preents us with a delightful View of the curious Frame of the Humane Body, and thence raies us to the Contemplation of the Ineffable Goodnes and Admiration of the Stupendious Widom of the Deity, viible in the erecting o Amiable and Harmonious a Fabric. Then MAN in the differing circumtances of Age, Sex, and Complexion, is offered us as the Object of our Speculation: So that the Author has
travered all the various Regions of the Microcom, and has notably decribed the mot remarkable Occurrences in that intellectual Sytem. The Deign of which, without all Controverie, is no other than to guide us in the practice of, and hew us the Comprehenivenes of that Ancient Sentence, Know thy Self. The Dicoure aims at the Knowledge of our Selves, at clear and ditinct Apprehenions of our own Natures, at a view of our whole Frame and Module: And altho nakedly conidered it be peculative, yet it is directly levelled at Practice, namely, to ait us in the regular Ordering and Governing our Lives and Actions: it were then undeniable madnes or conceitednes, to frown at, or hew a dilike of the Endeavours of others advantaging us in a larger Propect of our own Beings: If we blame others, and diparage their Labours
deigned for our Benefit, it is an apparent Demontration we maintain an over-winning Fondnes of our own Abilities; what others may object againt this Treatie, I am not able to conjecture, neither hall I be olicitous to enquire; but this I dare promie my elf, that uch as are acted with generous and ingenuous Souls, will be candid and favourable: But as for uch as applaud themelves for their admirable Faculty in Obtrectation and Raylery, and uch like diingenious Foolery, it were aburd to regard them. It is uually aid, and I wih it were more conidered, That its much eaier to quarrel at Mens Dicoures, than to frame one of a more even and methodic Compoure. To cenure Treaties of quable with them is no deperate difficulty, but to write others that hall in all repects wonderfully urmount them, is a Matter
of no great Facility. I confes a compleat meaure of Conidence may accomplih a Man for Drollery and Invectives; but there mut be other Ingredients to make him deerve the Denomination of truly Learned: And to uch as hall look on what the Author here Expoes to the Public, with an Eye of Didain and Contempt, its my humble Requet they would recommend to us omething of their own on the ame Subject, more worthy our Inpection and Perual, by which thing I am perwaded, they will highly gratifie the Author and pleae others. If Reader, the Authors Judgment and thine, may interfer (as its highly probable they may) let not that be cogent with thee to move thee to a dilike of what he offers thee. Thou perhaps judget thy Opinions to be founded on the plainet and clearet Evidence, when-as on the contrary, the Author preumes, and that it
may be not rahly, that his Sentiments are enforced with as convincing Demontrations as any. It were therefore unbecoming to precipitate thy Sentence of the Treatie, either in a way of Commendation or Detraction, till thou hat deliberately weighed and conidered the Deign, Matter, and Method of it. Let it be but admitted to plead at the Bar of Reaon, and I am confident the Author will be content to ubmit to any thing, that hall certainly be determined by that High Court of Judicature. What remains is only to recommend the following Dicoure to thy Candid Perual, hoping it may be of ome Benefit and Advantage to thee. Vale

div.head: On the ATHOR.
div.l: BEgon faint Limners, with your vain pretence,
Of Plainly Repreenting Man to Sene;
Your Art's defective, you cannot Pourtray
This Lively Image, vain is your Eay,
By Lines, and Lineaments, his Shape t' Expres;
That makes not Man, which is his Garb and Dres:
The Soul's the Man, your Colours are too Dark,
To give the Features of that Heavenly Spark.
Learn then of th' Author for he it is that knows
To Draw the Man as well as Paint his Cloaths.

div.head: A DISCOURSE CONCERNING MAN.
A Proemial Introduction.
div.p:
WHen God the Supreme Being (within the boundles circumference, of whoe Omnipotence is the poibility of effecting all things) in the beginning of time;The Creation of the World. by the Energy of his Puiance produced the Fabric of this World out of nothing, and caued this Viible Structure to
Emerge out of a confued Chaos. He firt animated that inert Matter, which he had created with the Mundane Spirit, which Vivifies the united Members of this Uniforme Globe; he caued the Vigorous Active Soul of the World to move upon the Surface of the Waters, and to agitate the Glideing Particles of that Fluid Element: This Univeral Soul by its • nergetic and Efformative Efficience Permeating, and Inhabiting all things, was continually fluctuating and never quiecent, till it had reduced its inordinate Domicil, to o harmonious an Order, to o regular and cononant a Situation, and to o elegantly Organized a Contexture as we now ee it Beautified with. This is that < in non-Latin alphabet > , that Pla • ic Principle, which by its Prolific Virtue preerves the Species of things, and multiplies their Individuals determinates the Forms, Shapes, and Configurations of the ame in their Generations. After this,Of Light. he caued the glorious Light to hine forth out of private darknes;
hereby the ubtances of Bodies were rendered viible,Des Cartes Princip. Philoophiae. and their Colours, Shapes and Figures, made conpicuous. This is caued, aith a Learned Philoopher, by the Conatus of the Globules of the econd Element, gathered together about their Center, to recede there from. Thee Lucid Corpucles, at their fir • t Creation, were equally expanded through the Regions of the Air; but now they flow and tream forth in a perpetual Current from their Center, or Fountain; thee Rays or Emanations of Light by the Intervention of any Opace Body are reflected, by the Interpoition of a Semidiaphanous Body are refracted, and they are contracted, and united into a Body of Fire, when they penetrate the • ores of a Burning-glas tending to a Conic Figure; to this Light God gave the Denomination of Day, and Darknes the Privation hereof, he called Night: When the Superfice of all things was apparent, and when thoe minute Lucid Corpucles did penetrate the tranparent
Body of the Air, then the Corucant, • plendid, and Effulgent Glittering of the Day was preent. But when thee Rays, which are certain tenuious treams of igneous Particles, in a continued Fluor, and ineffable pernicity, ucceeding each other in direct Lines, either immediately from their Fountain, or mediately from olid Bodies, reflecting towards the eye, and enibly affecting the ame; I ay when thee are obtructed by the interpoition of any Opace Body between us and their Fountain; that Light that is between us and the thing interpoing, doth preently fall down to the Earth, tending thereto by its own gravity, jut like a Conduit, or Water-cock ending forth a tream of Water; when we apply our hand to the Orifice, the Water falling down towards the Earth doth diappear: Thus the Earth whoe gros Body canot be permeated by the ubtile beams of Light, when it intervenes between us and the Sun, it caues the obumbrating Shadows of the Night to
appear. But to proceed in traceing the Footteps of the Divine Architect in the Works of Creation, till we come to that part we have deigned for the Subject of this little Treatie. The next thing that he did, was his commanding the Heavens to be Expanded like a Curtain, and Extended into a < in non-Latin alphabet > an Expane or Firmament;Of the Firmament. before the Word of Comma • d was gone forth, the Matter whereof this. Firmament doth conit, lay dormant in the < in non-Latin alphabet > . Tohu or Chaos, that Dene receptacle of all Corporeal Beings; where all Material Subtances were, Blended together: But when Omnipotence gave the Word of Command (Let there be a Firmament) there was uddenly made a great rarefaction, and ome of that gros Matter was quickly t • anubtantiated, and turned into an Aetherial Subtance; then thoe oeletial Orbs were wheeled about by the hand of Providence, continuing their regular Circumgyrations to the end of the World. The next thing that was done, was the
gathering together the Liquid Element of Water into its proper receptacle the Sea;Of Water. it was then, the Water was incorporated with thoe Saline Particles,The caue of the Salines of Sea water. and impregnated with a Salt, which is Congenite and Concreate with it; but when this Water is Percolated or Cribrated thro the Sandy,How it is made fresh. Nitrous, and Luteous Glebes of the Earth, or rarefied and evaporated by the warmth of the Subterranean Fire, it relinquiheth the Salt, which is nothing but the thicker and longer Particles of the Water, and o hereby is reduced to that ubdulcid Sapor, whereof our Fountain Waters do relih.

It was then that thoe Limpid Waves began to fluctuate, then the flux and reflux of the Sea had its firt beginning, not being caued by the Attractive Virtue of the Sun, nor by the Magnetic Influence of the Moon,Of the Motion of the Sea. as ome imagine; neither by the Etuation of the Subterranean Fire, cauing in it an Ebullition, like the Boiling of a Pot, as others fictitiouly conjecture; but
by the Motion of the Earth turning round upon its Axis once in a Natural Day; hereby the Water is agitated jut as Water in a Veel, the Veel being haken.

After this he commanded the Earth to fructifie and to yield its Vegetables: then the Prolific Sperm,Of the Generation of Plants. contained within the Clods of the Earth, began to ferment; and hence Plunts began to germinate. Now the creeping Moue-ear hoots forth its hairy Leaves; now the venomous Crow foot begins to pread its Claws; now the flourihing Alchimilla, or Ladies Mantle, adorns the Mountains of the Seprentrional Regions, and now the wild Tanie expands its Stems, beautified with Silver Leaves; now the Shepherds Pure dilates its Pouches; now the Scurvey-gras abounds with its Anticorbutic Leaves; and now the refrigerating Hounds Tongue begins to blab; now the Dandelyon exhibits its crooked Teeth, and Hore-tail extends its Knotty Briles; and the oporiferous Poppy is replenihed with its narcotic
Juice; now the Fields are every where inveted with their verdent Apparel, for Botanits to recreate themelves with: and now the Phytologits may write Volumes of Botanology. I hall not here preent the Reader with a Catalogue of Plants, it being too great a Digreion from our preent buines, but refer him to thoe Learned Botanic Authors, who have already ufficiently done it, as Johan Bauhin, Caper Bauhin, Gerard, Parkinon, and Mr. Ray in his late Elaborate Compendious Catalogue; neither hall I here decend into the Anatomy of Vegetables, nor penetrate into the Bowels of Plants, nor yet delineate the curious Contexture of their parts, it being a work, beides our preent deign, and ocing it is already o elaborately performed by Ingenious Dr. Grew.

We come therefore now to the next Operation,Of the Heavens and Celetial Luminaries. performed by God in Building the Fabric of this World, and that is, the Creation of the Sun, Moon, and Stars, thoe Celetial Luminaries, thoe fixed and
Erratic Lights, then thoe tranparent Chrital Spheres, in which the fixed Stars are fatned, were whirled about by the Primum Mobile; or rather thoe Lucid Bodies, and Globulous Flames began to wim in the Fluid Aether: The Sun performing its Annual coure, moving round the Eclyptic in the pace of a Year, and the Lunar Globe in its Monthly Circuit, performing the ame in a little more than Twenty even days; while the Earth, the Center of the Univere, where the more feculent and droy parts do reide,Of the Suns Motion, with the Motion of the Earth. is turned about upon its Axis in the pace of Twenty four hours, a < in non-Latin alphabet > or Natural day.

After thee things were fin hed,Of Living Creatures. he Created the Living Creatures; thoe Machins curiouly Fabricated by the chief Opifex of Nature, the Fihes of the Sea, the Fouls of the Air, the Beats of the Field, and every creeping Vermine, and Minute Inect.

Now God having thus replenihed the World with all its materials,Of the Creation of clan. beautified and adorned it with all
its requiites; the Morning Stars ang together, and all the Sons of God houted for joy, while he was making Man a Creature not much inferiour to them: Here he Epitomized thoe Mighty Volumes he before had elaborately wrought; this is that little World, wherein all the parts of the Macrocom did concenter; this is the Compendium of the Univere, the Wonder and Miracle of Nature, the Mirrour of Divine Widom, a Heavenly Coal blown up by the Divine Sparks of Infinite Prudence. What a perpicuous Analogy, what a congruous Parrellellim, what an exact Similitude hath Man with the whole World,Mans Anagoly with the great World. both in his Angellic, Heavenly, and Sublunary parts? The Soul, that Queen Regent in the Palace of the Brain, is the Anima Munduli, and repreents the Soul of the World; the Spirits repreent the Heavens, the Subtle and Aetherial parts of the Univere; the Four Humours bear a great Analogy with the Four Elements, Choler, that hot Sulphureous and Raging
Humour, is like the furious Element of Fire, the calmnes of the Blood is compared to the Serenity of Air, the dulnes of Flegm, to the Hebetude of Water, and the Adut Melancholy is like the Feculent Earth: Hairs repreent the verdent Vegetables; Bones and Stones in the Reins and Bladder, repreent Rocks, Stones and Minerals; the Veins and Arteries, the Rivers and Caverns of the Earth; the Circulation of the Sanguine Liquor, is a repreentative of the Motion of the Marine Waters, and of the Waters in the profound Abyes of the Terretrial Globe: Dew is repreented by Tears, Hail By Concocted Flegm, Rain by the Humours that fall into the Throat,See Crook's Body of Man. Thunder by Fury, Heat, Rumbling, Belching, and Winds by exhaled Crudities, Hiing, Singing and Ringing Noies in the Ears, &c.

Now if the cononant Order, harmonious Structure, and regular Compoure of the greater World, be not enough to confute an Atheit, here is enough to atonih him; if
the Contemplation of the Works of Creation, in reference to the Macrocome, will not lead him to the acknowledgment of a Deity and firt caue; here's that which will make it as Viible and Conpicuous as the Sun in its Meridian glory. Having cleared the way by this Brief Introduction, I hall without any further Remora come to the intended Scope of this Deign.

div.head: Chap. I. Of the Ditribution of Man into his Two Eential Constituring Parts.
div.p: ANthropology. The Two parts of Man. or that Doctrine which Treats concerning Man, may rightly be divided into Two parts, viz.
Pneumatology, which gives an account of his Soul, and Somatology, which is the Anatomy of his Body.

Man being defined a Subtance, coni • ing of a Spiritual and Rational Soul, and of a fitly compoed Body; in order therefore to the dicription of this noble Creature, we hall firt Treat of his more ublime and ruling part, his Soul; we hall endeavour to unfold the hidden Treaures, and Unlock thoe choie Curioities that are cloitered up in the Cabinet of this Pneumatic Science, and that this might be done after a Methodic manner I hall firt dicoure concerning the Nature of the Soul. Secondly, concerning its Origen. Thirdly, concerning its Union to the Body. Fourthly, concerning its Immateriality. Fifthly, corcerning its Immortality. Sixthly, concerning its Extenion; and Latly, concerning its Faculties.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Nature and Definition of the Soul.
div.p:
An Introduction to this Chapter.SEing the Soul is a Being, whoe: Nature is far above the reach, of Sene, inviible to the mot acute Acies of Corporeal Eyes, Intrectable by the mot enible Organs of Touching; it is mot evident that nothing can penetrate into the Bowels of this Golden Mine, or explicate the hidden Myteries therein contained, but the Soul it elf; he who is immaterial her elf, can bet by a reflex-peculation explicate the Nature of a Spirit, and truly this Work mut be et upon by the Soul, not with Rahnes or Temerity, but with diligent Rumination, erious Deliberation, profound Contemplation, and edulous Indutry: For what Pedantic notions of the Soul have been abtracted from the Brains of ome
(tho counted very judicious) by reaon of their Incogitance, others thro Critical C •• ioiry have broached ome Notions as ridiculous as the former thro Inadvertency. What a illy Fiction is that, That the Soul is the Form of Man? And how unprofitable are the Ditinctions and Diputes of the School-men, concerning Forms,That the Soul is not the Form of Man. in Order to the Abettment of this Hypotheis, is evidently manifeted by that never enough praied Peron the Honourable Robert Boyle. For it is mot agreeable to the Canons of Reaon, that Man being an Animal compounded of Two ditinct parts, a Rotional Active and and Cogitant Soul, and a fitly Adapted and Organized Body, each of which have their proper and particular Forms, hath no other Form (quatonus compoitum) than the Union between the Soul and Body.But that Union is the Form of Man. Plato was greatly deceived in Imagining the Body to be no part of Man; but that Man was nothing but a Soul, making ue of a Body as its Domicil, wherein it
is Incarcerated: But of all Opinions a more ridiculous could not have been invented than that the Soul is the Form of Man. Certainly this crackt the Cranny of him that found it out, ele he would never have vented uch Crack-brained Notions o frequently, one after another; yet uch was his Etime and Credit, that many will till, altho with as little Reaon as the Author himelf, indeavor to abett this Aertion, That the Soul is the Form of Man, not the Forma Informans, ay ome of them, but Forma Aitens, as they call it; jut as a Marriner in a Ship? yet who will be o arrogant to aert that a Marriner is the Forme of a Ship. But that I may a little demontrate this Diametrically oppoite Sentiment of mine, That the Soul can in no wie be imagined to be the Form of Man:Reaons to prove the Soul not to be a Form. I hall hew upon what Foundation this Aertion is etablihed; and firt, I ay the very Notion and Definition of a Form cannot in the leat be appropriated to the Soul; and it is
agreed upon by all, Cui non convenit definitio, ei neque definitum, beide the Peripatetic and pretended Definition of a Form, viz. Forma et per quod res et id quod et, is no more a Definition of a Form. than Oculus est per quod al quis vidit, is a Definition of the Eye. But a Form may be thus rightly Defined, Forma et ens incompletum materiam informans, unum per e cum materiâ contituens & distinuens ab omni a • os. It is an incomplete Being, informing Matter, and contituting one Eential. Being with the Matter, and ditinguihing it from every thing ele. Now, Firt the Soul is not an Incomplete Being; for an Incomplete Being is ome Mode or Accident which cannot ubit unles coexitent w • th a complete Subtance, but the Soul is a complete Being ubiting of it elf. Secondly, the Soul doth not inform Matter, if o, it would be the Form of the Body; for then there would be an Intrinic Communication of Eence and Eential Properties. We will grant there is a Preence, a Contact, a Diffuion,
an Union, and an Actuation, yet none of thee come under the Notion or Title of Information; and altho the Soul doth Actuate the Body, yet it doth not Communicate every Action to the Body, but performs many A • tions without any dependance thereupon; as Cogitative, Intellectual, and voluntary Actions: But now a Form depends upon Matter in every (if any) of its Operations. Again Thirdly, the Soul is not one with the Body, neither in Indentity as a Subtantial Act according to the Peripateric Philoophy) is the ame with the • ubtance; not by incluion or inherence, as a Mode or Accident is one with its Subject, but only in Compoition, as Two United Parts are one, which till retain their proper Eences, and can exi • t a part: So that the Soul is an Eential part of the Compoiu • um, and not the Form thereof. Latly, it is evident that the Specific difference and ditinction of Man is taken as well from one part as from the other: Man differs
from Angelic Beings in his Body, in his Soul from Inanimate Creatures; yea in his Soul there is omething which ditinguiheth him from Angels, and in his Body, whereby he differs from other Bodies: And as thee two parts are o fitly compoed and ordered, that they make one compleat Being, there are ome particular Forms, Properties, and Modes, which dicriminate him from all other things in the whole Sytem of this habitable Orb; as,
Os homini ublime dedit coelumque tureri
Juit & erectos ad idera tollere vultur, &c.

Now the definition which Aritotle gives of the Soul is far from explicating the Nature thereof, Aritotle's Definition the Soul, vidiculous and Pedantic. neither is it any way atisfactory, but Ignotum per ignotius explicans, explaining an unknown thing, by a thing abundantly more unkown; and that is this. Anima et
< in non-Latin alphabet > , ive actus corporis Phyici & Organici vitam habentis in potentiâ: The Soul
is an
< in non-Latin alphabet > , or an act of a Phyical; and Organic Body, having Life in Power. An unintelligible Coacervation of Non-ence, for who can interpret the meaning of Aritotle's < in non-Latin alphabet > I cannot Imagine, unles he do as Hermolaus a Famous Barbarian did, who when he had got ome Society and Colloque with the Devil, the Devil demanded of him, What he hould do for him? He aid he deired nothing more than that • e would explain unto him the word < in non-Latin alphabet > in Aritotle's Definition. Yea, I can truly ay concerning this, with a Late Author, in • â re nemo craius Aritotele peccavit qui talem protulit anima definitionem quae omnibus plene rebus corventr • t, & veluti commune emplatrum, vulueribus, omnibus inedetur, praeterea quid nobis ditincti per actusvocem innotecit, nihil amplius me Hercule, quam i quis lucem definiat actum corporis lucidi &, calorem actum corporis calidi. In this thing no body hath more groly erred than Aritotle, who brought forth uch a Definition of the Soul, which is
applicable almot to all things, and as a Common Plaiter heals all Wounds: Beides what would he have us to undertand by the word Act? Nothing more truly than if anv one hould define Light to be the Act of a Lucid Body, and Heat the Act of a Calorific Body. How maniet an Ambiguity (aith a Learned Writer) and how great an Obcurity is there in the word Act, or < in non-Latin alphabet > , which ome tranlate perfection? Such definitions as thee, are o far from augmenting our Knowledge, and encreaing our Literature, that they detrude us into inextricable Laby rinths, and obnubilate thoe things which in themelves are evident. Having thus laid down the reaon why we cannot Aent to the Definition of Artoile, it is now incumbent upon us to produce the true and genuine definition of the Soul;The true Definition of the Soul. Its Eence conits in Cogitancy. which is this: The Soul is an Incorporeal Cogitant Subtance, or a Subtance of a Spiritual and Incorporeal Nature, whoe Eence conits in Cogitation. This Definition is very
comprehenive, and very intelligible. The genus here acribed to a Soul is al Subtance, it is not a Model, an Accident, a Form or Quality; but a Being of a elf-ubiting Nature: It is a Spiritual and Incorporeal; Subtance, not an Igneous, Fiery, Flammeous, Avery, Aetherial, or any blementary Subtance, but a Subtance of higher Nature: It borrowed not its Origen from Matter, nor derived its Rie from any Corporeal Being; its very Eence and formal Reaon is Cogitancy: It never ceaeth from perfo • ming the Action of thinking, be the Body never o profoundly Dormant, be tho Animal Spirits never o Entoxicated, be the Brain never o much Stupified, the Soul is till Active, Cogitating, Ruminating or • ontemplating; it may be troubled, and diverted from being intent in it, Conceptions, but the Act of thinking can never be impeded; neither can any thing put an end to its Cogative Operations: There is no Narcotic Doe can caue the Soul to leep, nor any Anodyne Medicine
to Eutoxicate an Active Spirit: No, for when the Ventricles of the Brain are. Obtructed by Opium, the piified, Juice of Soporiferous Poppies, or when the Spirits are Locked up by Laudanum, a more refined and rectified Medicine, the Soul is o far from being attached by the Narcotic. Virtue thereof, that it is hereby rendered more intent in its Operations abtracted from. Matter. When the Body is quiecent,Cogitancy hath no dependance upon the Body. it is not o diverted by enible Objects, as it is in vigilance, when ome External Objects do always preent themelves to the Organs of Senation.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Origen of the Soul.
div.p:
HAving laid down the true Definition of the Soul, and reried the fality of Aristotle's Deinition, proved it to be purious and illegitimate in the precedent
Chapter: We now proceed to in Rie and Origen; and here we have to deal with a two-fold Antagonit Teh Firt are, Thoe that uppot the Soul to prae-exit, that is was created in the beginning of the World, and o had a Subittance long before it was united to the Body. The others are thoe that uert that the Soul is propagated, extraduce, or generated of the Soul of the Parents. If the firt Hypotheis were true,That the Soul doth not praexet. the Soul would have ome remembrance of its former condition, the things which it had cognizance of before it was incarcerated in the Body (as the Platonits imagine) would certainly be now recorded: for the Memory is a faculty of the Soul, and eential to the ame. And altho the Artcients did judge it altogether incongruous to bring God upon the tage perpetually; Cudworth's Intellectual Syteme of the Univere. and make him immediately interpoe every where in the Generation of Men, by the miraculous Productions of Souls out of nothing; yet if we well conider, we hall find that there may be very good reaon on
the other ide for the ucceive Divine Creation of Souls; namely, that God did not do all at firt that ever he could or would do, and put forth all his Creative Vigor at once in a moment; ever afterwards remaining a Spectator of the conequent reults. God might alo for other good and wie ends, unknown to us, reerve to himelf the continual exercie of his Creative Power, in the ucceive production of new Souls: The other is,Neither is it propogated Extraduce that the Soul is propogated Extraduce from the Soul of the Parent, but the aburdity of this Opinion, is evident enough from thee following reaons.Several Arguments againt the Souls Propagt 1977.
(1). This Hypotheis uppoeth the Soul of the parent to be Dicerpible, and o to Communicate its own. Eence to the Contituting the Soul of the Foet us, which can be granted to no Incorporeal Being.
(2) It uppoeth multitudes of Souls daily Created, which never come to perfection, as in Abortions, and Effluxes of Seed, and this uppofition cannot but too much derogate from the
Widom of the Divine Architect.
(3) Such is the Geneis of any thing as is the Analyis; but this is the Analyis of Man, that the Body hould return to the dut whence it came, and the Spirit to God that gave it; o that eeing the Spirit had its immediate Origen from God at its Creation, doubtles at its Diolution; it doth immediatly retuen to him.
(4) Were the Soul Generated Extraduce, it mut either be from the Soul, or from the Body of the Parent, not from the SOul; becaue nothing can be Generated of a thing Incorporeal, Incorpireal Beings do not come under ch alterations; not from the Body (quia nil dat quod in e non habet) Becaue no Incorporeal Thing can be produce out of a Thing Corporeal: Not from both, for then the Soul of the Partus would certainly participate of the Nature of them both, and o become a Subtance partly Corporeal, and partly Incorporeal.
(5) The only Way and Method of its being done, were it poible it could be
done, is enough to Induce us to believe the contrary; for then the Soul would be a Subtance Compounded of Two pieces of a Spirit, the one abtracted from the Spirit of the Male, the other from the Soul of the Famale Parent, and thee Two Pieccs or Paris Blended together into one, to Compoe a Rational Soul; which uppoal, how Irrational, Fictitious, and Ridiculous it is, any Rational Creature may preently apprehend.

The true Origen of a Soul viz. That it is immediately Created by God It reamins then that we lay down the true Origen of the Soul; which is, that it was immediately created by God, and infaed into the Body This Opinion, though it be ancient, yet everal coniderable reaons do incline me to believe it as Orthodox and Genuine, and the verity of it may eaily be manifeted, not only by the Confutation of the Two former Opinions; but from the Tetimony of Sacred Writ. viz. he formed the Spirit of Man within him.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the nion of the Soul to the Body.
div.p:
THe Soul being a Subtance of an Active and Vigorous Nature, God who is its Prime Parent, being the Father of Spirits, deemed it requiite to betow upon it a Body dilicately Fabricated; not only that this might be its Domicil wherein it hould lye IncarcerateThat Spirits tand in need of Bodies to Act in. (as the Platonits would have us believe) but he really intended that a part of a Spirits felicity hould conit in its Union to ome body or other, which it might make Ue of, as a compleatly Organized Machin, whereby the better to performe its Actions; therefore to Angelic Spirits he gave AEthereal, Lucid, and Star-like Bodies; to the Souls of Men, while they continue in thee Lower Regions, Terretial Bodies;
yet curiouly Fabricated and fit for their Motions and Operations; but when they are deveted of thee by the aaults of Death, then he orders them to enter into Aerial Vehicles, that o the eaier they may Soar into the inviible Regions of the Coeletial Habitacle, and to retain thee till the Reurrection, when they hall re-aume their former Bodies Transformed and Modified into the Nature of Angelic ones. But I hall refer a further Procedure upon this, till I come to the Immortality of the Soul, and hall here treat a little of the manner of its Union to thee our Bodies; This is a thing o ublime, that it trancends the reach of humane intellect to conceive; o capacious that it exceeds the limits of Reaon to comprehend, o abtrue and difficult, that it puzzels the Wits of all Philoophers to demontrate how Two Subtances, the one Spiritual, the other Corporeal, things of a quite contrary Nature hould contitute but one Compoitum; what Medium thee
can be found for their Union; by what means the more principal part doth Vivifi • and Actuate the part more inferiour; what moving Virtue it doth Exert and Communicate to the Body, and by what kind of contact this is done? Surely thee are things that none but he that is the Sole Author of thee Phoenomena can demontrate how, or in what manner they are performed; yet that they are performed is very apparent, and uch is the curioity of that buie and Pragmatic Creature Man, that he cannot contain himelf from Prying into the Caues of thoe things; the effects whereof declare them o to be, tho they are never o abtrue: He thinks there is nothing o locked up in the Cabinet of Nature; but by his diligence he may find the Key, or that there are no Rareties Treaured up in the Magazine of this Created World, that he by a diligent Scrutiny cannot find out: Some therefore will tell us, That in Man there are Three Eential parts, a Body, a Soul, and a
Spirit; the Body ay they, is a Subtance made of the Groer Matter, viz. Fleh, Blood, Bones, Nerves, Cartilages, Veins, Arteries, &c. The Soul is a Subtance tho Material, yet of an AEtherial and Subtilized Nature, Fiery and Flammeous, Participating both of the Nature of a Body and of a Spirit, and the Spirit which is their Third ingredient in their noble Compoition, is altogether Incorporeal United to the Body, by the mediation of the Corporeal Soul.

Others will affirm that the Soul being the Ruling part,The Carteians. its like a Queen in the Palace of the Brain upon her Throne the Conarion, which is a little Glans • lous Body almot in the midt thereof; there he Contemplates of the Regions of her Kingdom, and the Members of that Common-wealth, being always attended with her Viceroy the Animal Spirit, whereby he doth at Pleaure end an Embay into the mot Remote Parts of this little World thro the nerves. But how well the Authors or Abetters
of thee Two Opinions have hit the Mark. I leave to the Credulous Reader to determine; concerning the Firt, I hall only Query a few things;That the Soul is not United by the Mediatioc of the Corporeal Soul evinced by everal Queries.
(1) Whether it be ene to ay a Meterial Soul?
(2) Suppoe it be, whether there be any uch thing as they imagine by it in the Body of Man?
(3) Whether Body and Spirit be not things of a quite different Nature?
(4) Whether Rarefaction or Subtilization make a Body to be les a Body, or more a Spirit, than it was before?
(5) Whether a Red-hot Iron have any nearer Approximation to Life than it had before, or the Flame of a Candle, than the Extinguiht Snuff or Tallow of it?
(6) Whether this Corporeal Spirit be Semicorporeal and Semi-piritual? As for the Second Opinion, let me Query:Neither is it only United to the Glandula pinealis, and thence Influences the Body.
Firt, why the Soul hould it upon the Glandula pinealis more than upon any other part of the Body, and whence it appears that it doth? (2) Whether or no it be extended thro every part of the Conarion, or is only one point
of it? If extended thro every part, then why not as well thro the whole Body? If in a point how it Acts and Inluenceth the Body? (3) Whether this Virtue which the Soul doth Exert and Communicate in its Operations, be the Eence of the Soul or no? Now thee Two Opinions eeming to diagree with the Canons of Reaon and True Philoophy; it will not I hope be unkindly reented, if I exhibit another to the deliberate perual of the unprejudiced, which altho at the firt it may eem a little Uncouth; yet I am perwaded after ome Conideration, it will appear to be attended with leer Inducements, to make any Wie Man Incredulous of its verity than either of the former,But by its Extenion thro the the Body, it Actuates all its parts. and that is this, that the Soul is United to the Body by its Extenion thro every one of its parts; that the Soul is Extended, is not my buiens here to Demontrate, having deigned a particular Chapter for it, to which I hall refer the Reader, and where I hall endeavour to remove the
difficulties wherewith this Truth may eem to be burthened: If this then be proved, how eaily may we Imagine an Union of the Soul with the Body, to reult from its Extenion, and Diffuion thro the parts thereof?

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Immateriality of the Soul.
div.p:
THe Immateriality of the Soul is a Truth o Undubitably certain, and o generally believed, that thoe who have arrived to that height of Audacity as to deny it, are jutly looked upon to be no better than Atheits; for whoever is become o groly erroneous, as to believe his own Soul to be material, is conequently reduced (may I ay Blaphemouly) to Averr the Nullity of A Deity.
O Incredulity not to be parallelled! O Atheime, aburd and abominable! the Immateriality of the Soul may be evinced, Firt from its Activity, In-activity is a property pertinent to Matter, for Matter can exert no action of it elf, no not o much as Local Motion, unles it be agitated by ome External Caue, there being no uch thing as Natural Motion, Matter being a Thing Naturally Inert and Paive, but a Spirit which is of a Nature far trancending Matter, is always Active, and therefore Plato called. it < in non-Latin alphabet > , elf-moving, it is an imprevaricable Law with all Bodies, that nothing whatoever can move, unles it be moved by another; and hence it followeth that the Soul that moveth without being excited by any thing ele; Acting and Operating from its own Intrinic Power and Faculty, is of a higher Race than they,From its large Capacity and Dicurive Faculty. and conequently Incorporeal. (2) The large Capacity and Dicourive Faculty of the Soul Demontrates its Spirituality, when we conider the
multitude of things that are at once contained in the Soul; as likewie its Power of Exerting thoe Notions and Apprehenions, which it had Imbibed in Dicoure, how can we Conceive any otherwie than that he is Spiritual in her Eence. (3) Its Simplicity, Uniformity, Immortality, Self-reflection and Perfection, are Infallible Manifeto's of its Incorporeity; we may alo add Cogitation, a Property only Eential to a Spiritual Being;From Cogitation. for as we aid before, Matter cannot move it elf; how much les then is it able to perform that excellent Operation of deeming and thinking? I am not Inenible how ome do endeavour to evade this Argument, for a Late Author doth pretend to Solve the manner of Cogitation,Mr. Hobbs his Evaion. without recoure to an Incorporeal Principle; for faith he, the very Motion of Reaction of one part of Matter on another, or at leat the Continuation of this Reaction, can eaily effect this; for we find by experience, when we are Occupied in erious Meditations, or diligently
incumbent upon our Studies, a great Commotion in our Heads, and a kind of Confuion in the Parts of the Brain, which would not happen, except Perception and Cogitation did depend on Matter, and were made by the Motion and Agitation of the Particles of the Brain.

There might be ome probability in this,Its Solution. if the Author could drive us to believe that there was nothing ele but Matter in the whole Univere; but eeing this is altogether impoible, we hall condemn the other as fale and ridiculous; for if this were true, why may not alo the Bodies of Men, when defunct, be endued with the ame Power of Cogitation? For they are then no les capable of Reaction, or Suceptive of Corporeal Impreions; beides if we divide Matter into Monads, or Minute Phyic Particles; I Query, whether thee Monads being eperated one from another, may be capable of Perception and Cogitation, or only the Compoitum reulting
there-from? Now I think there is no one o a Friend to Atoms, that he hould think them to have Intelligence; for who can believe that the mallet Particle of Matter is indued with Sene and Perception? But if it be the whole Compoitum, what can be the Reaon that out of Inenible Things, hould Emerge Things capable of Sene and Apprehenion? How is it poible that from the various Coition of Atoms, which are Seneles and Incogitant, hould be produced a Cogitant Animal?

Having thus proved the Immateriality of the Soul,A Digreion concerning the Soul of Brutes. I mut crave leave here to make a little Digreion concerning the Souls of Brutes, whether their Souls be Immaterial or no? Concerning which, I hall Nominate Three Opinions, all which have been very plauibly received by many: Firt, The Opinion of the Lord Bacon, Dr. Willis and Gaendus, who who do thus Philoophize; viz.

That Brutes have a Corporeal
Soul, which being of an Ignite and Fiery Nature doth move the Organized Bodies of thee Animals: For this See Willis de Anima Brutorum, Du. Hamel, de Corpore Animato: Bacon's Natural Hitory, and Learned. Mr. Gales Philoophia Generalis.
Secondly, The Hypotheis of Renowned Des Cartes, viz.

That Brutes are nothing ele but Machins curiouly Fabricated by the chief Opifex of Nature; being Acted and Moved by no other than a Mechanic Motion, having neither Sene nor Perception in them; and this Opinion, aith Monieur Fernelius, eems to be taken from the Philoophy of Moes, where the Blood is aid to be the Life of Brutes. Le-Grand alo in his Book, De Carentia enus & cognitionis in Brutis, hath endeavoured to defend Des Cartes, and prove that Brutes are nothing but Natural Horologies, or Organs of Clock-work, being altogether as void of Sene, as Clocks performing their Motion the ame way.
The Third is the Hypotheis of Famous Derodon, Dr. More, and Dr. Cudworth, viz. That Brutes are Acted by an Incorporeal Soul, not differing in kind from Mans, but only in degree.

That Bruits have not Material Souls. From the Firt of thee I mut needs acknowledge my Dient, or contradict my elf in what I aid before; (yet till retaining that Reverence and Adoration I bear to the Learning of its Authors.) For I have already declared that there is contrariety between Matter and Spirit; o that a Material, or Corporeal Spirit, is a contradiction, and I have already aid, that Matter of it elf is Inactive Seneles and Inert: Dr. Cudworth's Sytem of the Univere. Neither can the Souls of Brutes, aith a late Learned Philoopher, be imagined to be Flame and Fire; for Flame and Fire is nothing but uch a Motion of the Inenible Parts of a Body, as whereby they are violently agitated, and many times diipated for begetting thoe Flames of Light and Heat in the Animals:
Now there is no difficulty at all in conceiving that Inenible Particles of a Body which were before Quiecent, may be put into Montion; this being nothing but a new Modification of them, and no Entity really ditinct from the Subtance of the Body; as Life, Sene, and Cogitation are; and therefore it is but a crude Conceit of Atheits and Corporealits, That Souls are nothing but Fiery and Flammeous Bodies; for tho Heat in the Bodies of Animals, be a neceary Intrument for the Life and Soul to act by in them, yet it is a thing really ditinct from Life. We might alo add, That according to this Hypotheis the Souls of Animals could not be Numerically the ame thro the whole pace of their Lives, ince that Fire, that needs a Pabulum to prey on, doth not always continue one and the ame Numeric Subtance; the Soul of a new-born Animal could no more be the ame with the Sould of that Animal Seven years after, than the Flame
of a new-lighted Candle is the ame with that which twinkles in the Socket; which indeed are no more the ame, than a River or Stream is the ame at everal ditances of time: Which Reaon may be farther extended to prove the Soul to be no Body at all, ince the Bodies of Animals are in a perpetual Flux.

Neither are they Inenible Machins. Concerning the Second Hypotheis, which is the Carteian, give me leave to ay with an Ingenous Author, Nec demum negaverim, inquit, animalium corpora ee Machinas miro artificio coagmentatas, ed nihil ee quam Machinas, qua nihil entiant, nihil agant ac pulu tantum agitentur alieno, id vero adduci non poum ut credam; at que eos qui contradicunt appello, an nullam in cane Venatico cum per compendia viarum leporem inequitur nullam in leporibus cum per varios flexus canes inequentes cludunt, nullam in betiis quae predâ vivunt, aut cognitionem immo & caliditatem & varios ut it a dicam artes animadverterunt?

I will not deny, aith he, but that the Bodies of Animals are Machins by admirable Artifice compacted together, but that they are nothing ele but Machins without Sene and Action, and only moved by Extern Impule, is a thing I can never be reduced to believe; and I challenge thoe that contradict me, to tell me, Whether in a Hungting Dog that follows the Hare the hortet way, or in a Hare indeavoring to delude the Dogs by her various turnings, or in thoe Beats that live upon the Prey, they have not oberved ome Cognition, Sagacity, yea may I ay Various Arts? What do thee Mechanics intend; who do not only deprive Brutes of Cognition, but alo of Sene? O aburdity contrary to common Experience! Do we not daily ee Brutes (I mean the more perfect ones) to receive Sounds in their Ears, and thereby excited to Labour, Meat, Drink, and divers Actions? And who will deny that a Dog, a Cat, or an Ape, do dicern their Food by Smells?
And certainly this Hypotheis was not dreamt on when this Ditic was made:
Nos Aper auditu, Linx viu, imia gutu,
Vultur odoratu: praeceelit Aranea tactu.

That Brutes are Seneles, and Inanimate things can no way be conceived; how then could Spiders o Geometrically weave their Cobwebs, and Bees o exactly form their Cellula's of an Hexagonic or Sexangular Figure? How could Foxes by that craft and cunning catch Birds, and deceive the Dogs that purure them? &c.

But that Brutes alo have Immaterial Souls. The Third Hypotheis then is that which eems to be mot Genuine and Rational: For if the Soul of Brutes be not Incorporeal, the Soul of Man can never be proved to be Incorporeal; for either all Concious or Cogitative Beings are Incorporeal, or ele nothing can be evinced to be Incorporeal
Thoe very things which we menrioned before to prove the Immateriality of the Soul of Man, are apparently to be een in Brutes, as Activity, Dicourive Faculty, Uniformity, Cogitation, Cognition, and Sagacity, and the Actions we daily ee performed by them, eem more like the Actions of Rational Souls than of Dead and Seneles Matter; as Doubting, Reolving, Inventing, &c. as is evident in Hawks, Dogs, Jaccals, Foxes, &c. and then by the Docility of them, and certain Continuate Actions of a long Tract of Time, o orderly performed by them, that they eem to argue Knowledge in them, rather than to proceed from Brutih Matter: Nay more, in ome Beats there is Precience of Future Events and Providences, the Knowing of Things never een before, and uch other Actions oberved in ome Living Creatures, which eem to be even above the Reaon that is in Man himelf. An Obje|ction. Neither indeed is the Objection of any conequence, which our Adveraries would retort
upon us, That this Hypotheis uppoeth alo the Souls of Brutes to be Immortal; which is a Notion dangerous and detructive (ay they) to the Rules of Chritianity.

To this I anwer, That there eems to be no great Reaon why it hould be thought aburd to grant Perpetuity of Duration, to the Souls of Brutes, any more than to every Atome of Matter or Particle of Dut in the whole World; o that this Objection hath nothing of validity in it; for they are Durable, whether Corporeal or Incorporeal: For Heaven and Earth, and all the parts contituting the ame, will never be annihilated, but metamorphized and changed: And o the innumerable Company of Souls that were created by God, may very well be uppoed to urvive their eparation from the <…> which they actuate; and o continue in a State of Immortality: being continually preerved by the Almighty Concoure of Him that created them. Not that I think the Souls of Brutes
to be capable of that Felicity or Miery the Souls of Men are; but we may either uppoe them to proceed from the Anima Mundi, or Soul of the World; which may alo be uppoed to be Immaterial, and o return to it at the Diolution; or rather, that when they are diveted of their Bodies, they take to themelves Aereal ones. Some there are that will not admit, but explode Aereal Vehicles; who uppoe, That the Souls of them urviving Death, doth o continue in a State of Inactivity, Inenibility, Sleep, Silence, and Stupor, until by a Tranmigration they re-aume new Bodies to act in: for while Spirits are diveted of Bodies, they cannot exert any Action. But this Suppoition would detroy our own Aertion alrady laid down concerning the Active and Cogitant Nature of the Soul. But leat I hould exceed my bounds, in too long a Digreion, I hall now come to the next general Head propoed in Order to treat on; and that is, The Immortality of the Soul.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Immortality of the Soul.
div.p: The Immortality of the Soul Proved FRom what hath been already alledged concerning the Nature, Origin, Union, and Immateriality of the Soul, may with great facility, and by necesary conequence be gathered its Immortality alo; and the fore-precedent things may erve for Topics, whence we may raie o many Arguments clearly to evince the ame.

From its Nature. The Nature of the Soul is o evident a Demontraitve of its Immortality, that whoever undertands the one, cannot but eaily apprehend the other. Is not Spirituality a plain Manifeto of a Durable Exitence; and Activity, and Cogitancy, and ineparable Concomitant of Immortality? How undeniably doth Plato, the Mirror of
the Mirror of the World for Learning, demontrates from the Souls being < in non-Latin alphabet > , Self-moving; that it is alo; < in non-Latin alphabet > , Ever-moving: Is it probable that thoe inetimable Creatures (whoe very Eence declares them to be made for a high or end), were created for nothing but to actuate thee Bodies; for a momentary pace, and then to return to nothing? Shall thoe Pious and Divine Souls, who for hopes of the Fruition of the endles Pleaures of another Life, have wich great alacrity and content of mind undergone the difficulties of this Mortal Pilgrimage, find nothing at the end of their Journey for their reward but a final annihilation? And hall the malevolent Slaves of the Devil, who have lavihed their Patrimony, and pent their days in erving the God of this World, and in doing Obeiance to their Luts and Debauched Appetites, be dicharged from the Penalty of their horrid Crimes by a Ceation of their Eence? What can prove a greater Derogation from the Equity of a
jut Creator, than o gros and Suppoition? Will He,From its Origin. who hath formed a Creature o like himelf, o oon detroy it? What can be a greater Reflexion on his Widom? Shall that puff of Divine Breath, which had its Rie from Gods Immediate Inpiration, ubide, vanih, and become a Non entity? Certainly That hand that could immediately produce a Being out of nothing, can by an Immediate Concoure preerve it from relaping into nothing again; neither are there any Motives to perwade him that can do this, to will the contrary: Were the Soul generated from the Parent, it might then be corruptible, but it hath its Origin from a higher Principle, it mut needs the • be of a Nature more lating, permanent, and durable.

From its Union. Its Union alo is another Tet o • its Immortal Exitence, if it were united to the Animal Spriit by in near Approximation to the Nature of it, or if fixt and fatened to the Pineale Glandule, this might be a plauible Pretext to make us entertain
ome thoughts of its Mortality and Perihing with the Body; whereby it is o much influenced: but eeing its Union is caued by its permeating the Body, and extending and diffuing it elf thro every part thereof; and o by a vigorous Energy actuating the ame, certainly all uch Imaginations conceiving it Mortal, are now baniht and exploded.

Our Fourth Topic is not likewie empty of proof to demontrate this Truth.From its Immateriality. Were the Soul a Subtance compounded of the Four Elements or Five Chymic Principles Blended together, we hould have little reaon to plead for its Immortality, becaue all Corporeal Things are ubject to Corruption, and have that within the verge of their own Eence, that in time will caue a Diolution in them, Nam contraria contraiis destruuntur. For Contrary Things are detroyed by their Contraries, and all Mixed Bodies have within themelves Qualities (may I call, them o) repugnant one
to another; but the Soul, as hath already been proved, being of an Immaterial Nature, is not obnoxious to any uch Caue of Mutability: And Nature it elf teacheth us, That whatoever hath a Being, will be poeed of it, until it meet with omething to detroy it: But now what contrary Principles, oppoite Elements, or repugnant Qualities, can Pycotomits or Anatomits of Souls (I mean thoe that hold them Material and o Mortal) find in the Analyis of Spirits? There are maty more Arguments of undubitable Verity and undeniable Evidence, to evince the Souls Immortality; as its Infinite Deire of,More Mediums to prove the ame. and its Solicitude about an Immortal State, in Diatisfaction under all the Felicities of this Life, and vehement Appetite and Deire after Eternal Beatitude; the Fear of Death, the Remores and Stings of Concience which all Men fall under upon the Sene of Guilt. But the Largene of the Subject, and the intended Brevity to which I have limited myelf, will admit only of a Tranitory
Glance upon every Thing that occurs to our Speculation.Of the Stale of the Soul after Death, that it doth not leep. Having therefore proceeded thus far, I hall add a little concerning the Manner of the State the Soul remains in immediately after its Diolution from the Body, and that it, That I do not believe, as ome do, That it remains in a State of Sleep and Stupor, till the Reurrection, but that it takes up an Aereal Vehicle, and hereby its Motion is made Feaible; which if the Soul were devoid of a Body, it would be impoible to perform. If the Soul, immediately after its Separation from the Body, pas not only into a State but a Place either of Eternal Miery or Everlating Happines, it is contrary to the Laws of Nature it hould be carried thither without a Body;That Souls aume Vehicles after Death. for Loco motion is a Property of Bodies, and no way to be performed by Spirits eparate from Bodies.

p.hi:
Beides (to argue for Vehicles) it is a Priviledge proper only to the Deity, to live and act alone
without Vital Union with a Body.
It is Natural to a Soul to inliven a Body, and therefore it is not probable that it hould be kept o long in an Unnatural State of Separation.

div.p: Again, It is more than probable from Scripture, That the Souls of Wicked Men after Death have Punihment of Sene and Pain, beides Remore of Concience. But let ome out of prejudice hould condemn this Opinion of Vehicles, as an Opinion newly feigned and foited into Phyloophic Books, more out of Novelty than Probability; or as an Aertion dangerous or inconitent with true Faith and Religion;Vehicles owned by the Ancient Fathers. I hall produce now the Tetimonies of ome of the Ancient Fathers, who were the Abettors of this Hypotheis.
Tertullian and Irenaeus were of this Perwaion, Origen alo was of the ame mind: Viz.

That Souls after Death have certain Subtil Bodies, retaining the ame Characterizing Form which their Terretrial Bodies had; and that the Apparitions of the Dead, are the Souls themelves urviving in a Luciform Body. Augutine alo granteth, That Souls after Death cannot be carried to any Corporeal Place, or locally moved, without Bodies. Nor is it conceivable how Imperfect Beings could have Sene or Imagination without Bodies, aith Origen: For, Origen contra Cel. aith he, It is the nature of an Incorporeal Thing, always to tand in need of a Body uitable to the Place wherein it is. And altho I mut confes Origen did maintain ome things contrary to the Doctrine of the Church, yet his Authority is no les Authentic for this thing than the Authority of the ret; becaue this was never reckoned in the Catalogue of his Errors.

Let me adde likewie, I That our Saviour's bidding his Diciples feel him,The ame implicitely evidenced from Scripture, and from Moes and Elias appearing upon the Mount. And from all other Apparitions. and telling them a Spirit had not Fleh and Bones, that is, no Solid Body, eems to imply that
they have Thinner Bodies, which they may viibly appear in: And alo Moes and Elias viibly appearing upon the Mount, argues, That they had real Viible Bodies.

Hereby likewie we may very eaily olve the Phaenomena of the Apparitions of Men and Women after their death, without imagining that they take up their Bodies when Defunct, and walk about with them; or that thee Bodies are actuated by the Devil; for then they would become Objects of the Sene of Feeling: but thoe that have een uch Apparitions, do declare the contrary, finding no reitance when they trike at them: Likewie their vanihing and eeming to penetrate Doors or Walls, hews they are not thoe Bodies; and certainly they cannot be uppoed to be the Souls themelves • eperate from all Body; for they are never viible. But if we will admit this Hypotheis of Vehicles, we may eaily imagine how they retain their Viibility, by cauing only a Reflexion of
Light, and loe their Tractability by reaon of their Tenuity and Rarity.

Now at the Reurrection,Of the Reurrection and New Modification of the Body. thee Souls which have dwelt thus long in Vehicles, do re-aume thoe very Numeric Bodies which before they depoed; yet not uch gros corruptible ones as they then were: For the happines of Souls coniteth not in their Conjunction with uch gros Terretrial Bodies as thee we now have; Scripture as well as Phyloophy complaining of them as a heavy: load and burthen to the Soul but the Soul at the Reurrection will aume a Body Immortal, Incorruptible, Glorious, and Lucid, Star-like and Spiritual. Heavenly and Angelic, not this Flehy Body gilded and varnihed on the out-ide only, but changed thro-out: Our Souls are Strangers and Pilgrims in thee Terretrial Bodies, their proper Home and Countrey is their Heavenly Body; thee very Bodies we now carry about with us, hall then be
transformed and modified into a Heavenly Form; and this is very agreeable with the Principles of Nature; for according to Phyloophy, the Groet Body, may by meer Motion be reduced to the Rarity and Tenuity of the Finet Aether; and if thus, what then cannot the Wie Fabricator of Heaven and Earth perform?

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the Extenion of the Soul.
div.p:
HAving already aerted the Extenion of the Soul thro the Body, it is requiite I hould a little demontrate, or at leat explicate, my meaning in this my Asertion; then if I remove thoe Difficulties which this Hypotheis may eem to labour under, and manifet the contrary Asertion to be attended with far more and greater difficulties, I
hope I hall have performed my promie. As for the Objections againt the Souls Extenion, I know but two that have any thing of validity or cogency in them; nor they neither, when rightly conidered. The Firt is this, viz.

That this uppoeth the Soul to be Material, for ay they, Extenion is an Eential Property of Bodies,Cartes Princ. Phil. Pars 1. Sect. 4. and applicable to no other Creature; yea ays Cartes, The very Nature and Eence of a Body coniteth in nothing ele but Extention.

To this I anwer, That both Reaon and Experience attet the contrary; for were Extenion a Property only pertinent to Matter, then the Notion of a Vacuum, proved by unanwerable Arguments,Arguments to prove a Vacuum. and demontrated by viible Experiments, mut be quite exploded: Are not Local Motion, Rarefaction, Condenation, Levity, and Ponderoity, the Corporeity of Light, and its Expanion thro the Air, Rational
Grounds to induce us to believe that there are certain Dieminate Vacuola in Bodies? Which Mediums you may ee exceedingly well promoted by Renowned Gaendus,
Gaendus in Epicurum. a Learned Senator of Epicurus, and Eminent Dr. Charleton,
Charleton's Philoophy. a Proelyte of Gaendus; but if Reaon will not evince, let Experiments demontrate. The Torrecellian Experiment, o often mentioned in the Elaborate Works of the Royal Society, is an infallible Proof hereof: And hath not the Honourable Robert Boyle,
Boyle's Phyico-Mechanic Experiments. made it indubitably certain by his Excellent Intrument the Air Pump. How this Experiment is performed by it, you may ee in his Phyico-Mechanic Experiments. Alo the Experiment of the Aeolipile doth plainly evince it: And urely Dr. Henhaw,
Dr. Henhaw's Aerochalinos. Member of the Royal Society, doth uppoe the being of a Vacuum, when in his Aerochalinos he lays down a Method of Building of a Domicil to change the tate of the included Air,A Vacuum demontrated by Experiments. by letting it out and in at pleaure. This is o evidently demontrated
by our late Ingenuous Philoophers, that I think none now (but thoe who thro prejudice are reolved to penetrate no farther into the Bowels of Nature, or make no deeper Scrutiny into the Myteries of Philoophy, than is conitent with the Old Phyloophy, or than the Ancient Libels lead into) can be o Irrational, as to deny it: I hall therefore alo, as the Writers of this Age do, take it for granted, and make this my Medium to beat down the Pretended Maxim; viz. That Extenion is a property eential to Matter; for if there be a Vacuum, then undoubtedly there may be Extenion without a Body; and then Extenion is no les congruous to Incorporeal than to Corporeal Beings. Thee Corporealits are quite mitaken in the Notion of Space, for by it we do not mean Superficies corporis ambientis, The true Nature of Space. as Aritotle feigned, and whom Cartes eems to abett in his Princip. Phil. Part. 2. Sect. 15. Nor as Cartes really expreeth, Sect 11. a thing not really
different from a Corporeal Subtance; but a real Entity, ditinct from all other Beings: for En •
being the mot General Genus, is not o narrow, as to admit of a Diviion, but into two parts; viz. Subtance and Accident: but the genuine Diviion of En •
is into Subtance, Mode, Space, and Time; which two lat are more general than the other, and can no way be comprehended under either of them. Having thus manifeted the fallacy and invalidity of the fore-mentioned Objection, I hall now proceed to the other, which is,

That if the Soul be extended, it is then diviible; for, ay they, if it be extended, it is contituted of parts; and whatoever is o, may be divided. Now to uppoe the Soul to be diviible, is very Aburd and Irrational.

To this I alo anwer, That by Extenion I do not mean a rendering a Thing liable to actual diviion,
but a real amplitude of Eence. Extenion is not the Ratio formalis of Bodies,Wherein the Nature of Extenion doth conit. but only as Dr. Glion in his Book De Natura Subtantiae Energetica, aith, An Accidental Property; which belongs to all Subtances both Material and Immaterial: Beides, I grant that Spirits are diviible Intelectually, but Phyically Indicerpible; for what is Intellectually diviible, may be Phyically Indicerpible; as it s manifet in the Nature of God, whoe very Idea implies indicerpibility; the contrary being o plain a Contradiction.A Dif • nction between Diviible and Dicerpible, and that the Soul is Mentally Diviible, tho Actually Indicerpible. By Intellectual Diviibility, I mean nothing but that Spirits being extended thro a diviibile Space, with the Diviion of the Space there may be a Mental Diviion of the Spirits in it; but Dicerpibility is, when a Thing may actually be eperated one part from another; this is no way congruous to a Spirit. So that a Spirit may be diviible, altho Indicerpible; which may erve for a ufficient Solution to this Objection.

The Difficultes that attend the other Hypotheis are unanwerable; That the Soul is not Totum in toto & totum in qualibet parte Corporis; as the Peripatetics aert. If the Soul be not extended, we mut either uppoe it to be, Totum in Toto & Totum in qualibet parte corporis, The whole Soul in the whole Body, and the whole Soul in every part of the Body; as the Peripatetics imagine it to be: Or ele, That it exits but in one particular Point, and then virtually actuates the whole Body: Which Suppoals, how contrary to Reaon they are, need not much Demontration. As for the Firt, there is no contradiction I ever yet heard of, can parallel it; for it is as much as to ay, That One and a Thouand, are one and the ame number: For we will uppoe the Body to be contituted of a thouand parts (which it may very eaily be divided into) and that if a whole Soul can be eentially in every one of thee parts, we mut needs then uppoe there to be a thouand whole Subtances; and how thee thouand whole Subtances hould be but one whole
Subtance, is not only inexplicable but irrational and inimaginable: If the whole Soul (that is, every thing of the Soul) be in the little finger, who can poibly imagine any thing of it, much les its total Subtance, to be in any other part of the Body; unles they will alo affirm, That Spirits have a peculiar power of being preent in many places at one and the ame intant; and o rob God of the Attribute of his Omnipreence: making Spirits to participate of the ame.

The next Suppoition, Tho an immediate conequence of the Non-Extenion of Spirits (for if they are not extended thro a Space Diviible, they mut needs be limited to an Indiviible Point) is not much les aburd;Neither is the Soul in an Indiviible Point. for how then can it be united to the Body, and as I aid already, how can it exert any action upon the Body? They will ay, Perhaps, it operates upon the Body virtually, by cauing a virtual Impule upon the Organs of it; but this virtue mut be either omething of the Eence of the
Soul, or omething ditinct from it: If it be the Eence of the Soul communicated to the Body, then its Extenion is granted;Its Extenion hence undeniably demontrated. but if it be omething ditinct, I anwer, Nill dat quod in e non habet. Some of the Aertors of the Souls Exitence in a Point, are poeed with uch merry Conceits of Spirits, as to imagin that a thouand Souls can dance upon the point of a Needle at one and the ame time, See Dr. Move's Divine Dialogues; p. 1. and have room enough to tread their Paces.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Faculties of the Soul.
div.p:
BY the Faculties of the Soul,What the Faculties of the Soul are. we are not to undertand things really ditinct from the Humane Soul, nor each from other; as the Aritoteleans would have the Undertanding and Will to be but only
different Modes and Ways of the Souls Operation, pecified by their Formal Objects and Acts. Thus as it forms Idea's and Notions of Things, it may be termed the Undertanding; but as it is allured by the goodnes of the Object, and thence moves towards it, it may be termed the Will.How the Undertanding and Will differ. Gale's Philo. Generalis. The Undertanding is converant about its Object, as true, the Will about its Object, as good: As the Soul doth contemplate, deliberate, judge, dicoure, and conclude, it may be termed the Undertanding; but as it chooeth, proecutes, or avoids an Object, o it may be termed the Will. Now the everal ditinct Modes of the Souls acting, are commonly reduced to five Heads; which make the ame number of Faculties:The Number of the Faculties. and they are the Undertanding, the Will, the Concience, the Affections, and the Memory.

The Undertanding is called by the Sacred Philoopher,Prov. 20.27. The Candle of the Lord. This is it that governs the inferior Faculties,The Undertanding. epecially the Imagination and the Phantaie;
the Formal proper Object of the Intellect is Truth,Its Formal Object Truth. which as one very well aerts, is congeneal and nearly allied to the Mind: It hath Nine Intellectile Habits, Opinion, Experience, Imitation, Faith, Sapience, Intelligence, Science, Prudence, and Art; to which, ome adde Cognition; which is < in non-Latin alphabet > , a Repreentamen of a Thing in the Intellect.

The Will by Plato is defined,The Will.
< in non-Latin alphabet > , a Deire with right Reaon, or < in non-Latin alphabet > , a Rational Appetite.

The Action of the Will is two-fold, the one conits in effectu, the other cum affectu; from which Ditinction that Common Ditribution of Voluntary Humane Actions into Elicit and Imperate, had its Origin, the Object of the Will is Good,The Object of the Will good. and that which terminates and bound • its Appetite finally is the chiefe • Good and lat End.

The Concience no ditinct Faculty.The Concience is a Reflexion of the Undertanding upon Man's Actions, together with a Sentencing them to be either Good or Evil
according to thoe unquetionable Pinciples already received; Dr. Ames. or it is the judgment of man concerning himelf; as it is ubjected to the Judgment of God. So that properly the Concience is no ditinct Faculty from the Undertanding; this is that,Prov. 22.27. Search that which is made by that Candle of the Lord in the lower parts of the Belly. It is called a Judgment, that thereby it may be ditinguihed from a naked Apprehenion of the Truth; for it always contains in it a firm conent; and we do not take Judgment here for an Habitual only, but alo for an Actual Judgment.

The Affections not ditinct from the Will.The Affections alo do not properly make a ditinct Faculty from the Will, the Voluntas in affectu, or the ellicit root thereof; God being the Object of the Will, having many Kinds and Degrees, according to the different manner of the Souls conideration of it, it excites different Affections in the Will; and firt of all, when any thing good or convenient, or at leat o apprehended by us to be, is repreented
to us; it preently excites in us the Paion or Affection of Love to it,Cartes. that we proecute it with a deire, that it may either be united to us, or remain with us; but on the contrary, when any evil or noxious thing is expoed to us, it immediately timulates us to Hatred the oppoite Affection: to Love as it is an Affection of Union with preent Good is often joyned Joy, and to Hatred Sadnes; and when there is a full and perfect poeion of this deired Good, then there is pure Love, and olid and incere Rejoycing; but when there is not a perfect Fruition of the thing beloved, then Deire is joyned with Love, and Sadnes is mixed with Rejoycing. Likewie, with a deire of Abent good there is mixed Hope and Fear, according to the probability of a good or evil Event, Iue, Effect, or Conequence of the matter; which Hope, if it be very great, is called Faith and Confidence; but when mall or no hope is mixed with abundance of fear, it degenerates into thoe purious
Affections of Unbelief and Depair. Thee Affections, epecially Love and Deire, do vary and differ much, according to the Opinion we have of the value of the Object; for when the intrinic or inward perfection and pulchritude of the Object is only look'd upon, then there is a Love of Complacency, and the Object is properly aid to pleae; to this is oppoed an Averion from an Object, by the conideration of the contrary Imperfection and Deformity, but when we conider of this Perfection as convenient for our elves, and ee it agreeable with our Nature;How Love is caued, its everal kinds. this Love of Complacency is turned into a Love of Concupicence, which is another Affection of the Soul, and properly another kind of Love. Again, When the Lover hath a les eteem of the Object than of Himelf, there thence arieth a imple Propenion, which is called Benevolence. Thus we love a Flower or Bird, &c. When we love an Object equally with our elves, thence prings Friendhip
