and Charity, and uch is the Love of Parents to Children, and Conjugal Relations one to another; but when there is a higher Valuation of the Object than of our Selves, as we all ought to have of God, our Prince, City, Countrey, Parents, and Friends, that are • eminent in Vertue and Merits, this kind of Love is called Devotion. Among all the Affections and Paions of the Soul, Love bears way;Love the chief Affection of the Soul. for the everal Affections of the Will, are but various Forms and Shapes of Love, which gives wift Wings and trong Legs to the Soul, to purue what it loves. There is no Affection of the Soul but Love hath it at command; the Will governs all inferiour Faculties of the Soul; but he is governed by Love. Plato makes Love to be the great Hero that governs the World, o univeral is its Empire and Dominions. If the Object beloved be abent, then Love fixes the Will with ardent deires after it; if the Abence be attended with Difficulties or Affronts, than Love goes forth by
Anger and Fear, to conflict therewith; and Hope with Courage, for the attaining the Object beloved. If the Good be preent, then Love embraceth it with Complacence and Delight; if lot, then it bewails its los with Sorrow, and according to the Nature and Meaure of the Love, uch will be the Nature and Meaure of the other Affections that iue from it: But we will ay no more of the Affections.

The Memory.The Memory is that Faculty of the Soul, whereby it treaures up thoe things it hath received; this is the Magazine of Notions, it is the Souls grand Repoitory, wherein it reconds its Riches, and draws them forth according to Pleaure.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the Parts of the Body.
div.p: HAving thus far conidered Man in his more Sublime, Superior, and Coeletial Part, we now decend to that Part which is Inferior, and more Terretrial; viz. The Body.

And indeed it is not a Work, much les difficult, accurately to delineat • the Parts of the Body, than to explicate the Nature of the Soul; th • the manner of acquiring Knowledge in both thee Parts is much different. For the one is done by Profound Contemplation, the other by Ocular Inpection; the one by a Mental Notional Penetrateing into the Bowels of a Spirit, the other by a • Actual and Manual Diection of Bodies. As for the Doctrine of the firt, which is < in non-Latin alphabet > , Pneumatology, we have already handled it
We come now to the Somatologio Part, which is trictly called, Anatomy: Anatomy its Subject. Anatomy then is a Science which hath the Body of any Animal for its Subject, whether Terretrial, Volatile, or Aquatile; yet among the number of Animals, the Body of Man is to be preferred, both becaue of the Pefection of its Parts, and becaue endles would be the Diection of other Animals; they being almot innumerable: and likewie becaue of the incredible Conducement of Anatomizing Humane Bodies, both for preerving and retoring the Health of Man: But eeing the Bodies of Men defunct are not always at hand, it hath been a Cutom of Ancient tanding, even among the Learned, to Diect the Bodies of other Living Creatures. Democritus by his frequent Diection of divers orts of Animals, is aid to have firt found out the proper Seat of the Bile. Galen alo accutom'd himelf to the Diection of Apes and Monkies. Severinus, Catellus, Bronzerus, Panarolus, and many others,
were wont to Diect the Bodies of dead Dogs: But Aellius, Dr. Harvey, Walleus, Bartholine, Pecquet, De Graaf, and others, did frequently cut open Dogs, while they were alive, and hereby found out the Lactean Veins, the Circulation of the Blood, the Thoracic Veins, the Lymphaducts, the Ductus Pancreaticus, with its Acid Juice, and many other ueful Inventions, by their diligent Scrutiny and Autopy. But our Dicoure is to be limited to the Humane Body, having choen Man to be the ole Subject of this Treatie. The Body of Man therefore, as it is a Totum Quantitativum eu Integrale, is divided by Galen and Hypocrates into Continentia, The Diviion of the Parts of Mans Body. Contenta, & Impetum Facientia; that is, into Solid Parts, Humours, and Spirits. The Body of Man may alo be divided either Ratione Finis or Ratione Materiae. Ratione Finis. The Principal Parts. They are either Principal Parts, or les Principal Parts: The Principal Parts are the Liver, the Heart, and the Brain; and the Vulgarly received Opinion
is, That the Veins have their Origin from the Liver, the Arteries from the Heart, and the Nerves from the Brain; which they ay are the Veels that convey the Natural, Vital, and Animal Spirits thro the Body.

The les Principal Parts, are either neceary,The les Principal parts. which are thoe without which an Animal cannot live, as the Lungs, the Ventricle, the Intetines, the Veicula Bilaria, the Porus Bilarius, the Veica rinaria, &c. Or not neceary, as Caro Simplex, in repect of the other Parts.
Ratione Materiae, the Parts are either Simple, Homogeneous, and Simular; or Compound, Heterogeneous, and Diimular.

The Simular Parts are Ten.The Simular. The Bones, the Cartilages, the Ligaments, the Membranes, the Fibres, the Nerves, the Arteries, the Veins, the Fleh, and the Cutis. The Diimular. The Diimular Parts are the Members of the Body, coniting of various Simular Parts. They are alo called Partes Organicae eu Instrumentales. But the Modern and mot Rational
Diviion of the Body is into its Venters and Artus.The Diviion of the Body into its Three Venters and Four Artus. The Venters are Three, the Infimus, the lower Venter, or the Abdomen, which contains the Liver and the Natural Parts, the Medius Venter, or the Thorax, which contains the Heart and Vital Parts; the Venter Supremus, or the Head, wherein is contained the Brain and Animal Parts.

Having given the Diviion of the whole Body,The Lower Venter its parts. we hall now begin with the Lower Venter; and this is all that Cavity, which within is ditinguihed from the Thorax, by the Diaphragm, circumcribed by the Cartilago Eniformis, the Os Pubis, Coxendicis, and the Os Sacrum, the Vertebrae of the Loins, and on both ides by the Batard Ribs; the Fore-part of this is called Epigatrium, the Lateral uperior Part of which is called Hypocondrium, which is next to the Inferior Cartilage of the Cotae.

The Middle is Regio mbilicalis, the two lateral Parts of which Aritotle calls < in non-Latin alphabet > , a Laxitate; and
Galen
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Inania. The Lower Part is Hypogatrium, which decends from the Regio mbilicalis down to the Regio Pubis, the Lateral Parts of which are called Ilia, and in Flexu Femoris ad Pubem Inguina, or the Groin.
Now this Venter conits of Exterior and Interior Parts.

The Exterior or Continent Parts, are either Common, which belong alo to other Parts of the Body, as the Cuticula, the Cutis, the Pinguedo, with its Membrane, the Panniculus Carnous and the Membrana Muculorum propria; or Proper only to this Venter, as the Mucles of the Abdomen and the Peritoneum.
The Interior or Contained, are thoe that erve either for Nutrition or for Procreation.

Thoe that erve for Nutrition, belong either ad
< in non-Latin alphabet > to Chylification, as the Ventricle, the Omentum, the Pancreas, the Intetines, with the Meentery, the Lactean Veins, with the Common Receptacle and the Lymphatic Veels; or ad
< in non-Latin alphabet > to Sanguification, as
the Meeraic Veins, the Vena Porta with its branches, and the Vena Cava, the Liver, the Veicula Bilaria, the Spleen, with the Vas Breve and the Hemorrhoids, the Arteria Celiaca, the Veins, the Capulae Atrabilariae, the Ureters and the Bladder.

Thoe that erve for Generation are Vaa Spermatica, the Corpora Varicoa or Paratatae, the Tetes, the Vaa Deferentia, the Protatae, the Veiculae Seminariae and the Penis, in Women the Vaa Ejaculatoria and the terus.

Having thus divided the Lower Venter, we come now to peak of each of its parts in particular; and the firt is the Cuticula
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,The Cuticula. this is a thin and cloe Skin, void of Life and Sene, without Blood, made of unxious, cras, and vicid Vapours, condened by the Circumambient Cold, to cover the Cutis, it is thicker than the Cutis, leat there hould be too great an efflux of Spirits and Heat; it is generated of an Excrement that hath its beginning in the Womb, and afterwards its perfection,
and this is the reaon why Infants newly born look o red as they commonly do. In Moors and Aethiopians it is black.

Next to this is the Cutis,
The Cutis. which is the Common Covering of the Body, generated of Seed and Blood, the Intrument of Touching and the Defence of the Parts that are under it; it is perforated in various places, for the ingres and egres of that which is neceary; thoe Perforations that are conpicuous, are the Mouth, the Ears, &c. The Inenible are the Pores, in this ther • are oberved everal Nervous Filaments, which Learned Carteius calls the Organs of Sene,Cartes de Homine. which being moved by External Objects, do accordingly make an Impreion upon the Brain.

Under the Cutis is ubjected the Pinguedo or Fat,The Pinguedo, or Fat. which is a Simular Body without Sene, made of unxious Blood concreted by the Cold of the Membranes for the defence of the whole; it is not in thoe parts where it would hinder a convenient complication, as in the Brain, the
Palpebrae, the Penis, the Scrotum and the Tetium Membranae; its Veels are the three Veins of the Abdomen, the Mamillary Veins, the Venae Epigatricae & elumbis emergentes, its ue is like a Garment, to keep the Body warm, to fill up the paces between the Mucles, the Veels and the Skin, to make the Body even, mooth, and round; hence Lean Perons, Old, and Withered, are Deformed. Next is the Membrana Carnoa, which is connexed to the Cutis by many Veins and Arteries: The Membrana Muculorum propria is a thin Skin connexed to the Mucles by mall Filaments, its ue is to cover the Mucles and eperate between them.

Next appear the Ten Mucles of the Belly.The Mucles of the Belly. A Mucle is an Organic Part, coniting of divers mall Fibres, an Intrument of Motion, the beginning of a Mucle is called a Ligament, the middle part is flehy, and the end is called a Tendon; every Mucle is furnihed with a Nerve. Of the Ten Mucles of the
Abdomen, two of them are obliquely decending, two obliquely acending, two right, two tranvere, and two pyramydal, thus nominated from the poition and ituation of their Fibres. Under thee Mucles is the Peritoneum,
The Peritoneum. which is a Membrane of an Oval Figure, inveting the Bowels; it hath its Origin at the Spine, and the firt Vertebra of the Loyns, its ue is to contain the parts, and to hut the Orifices of the Veins; among the parts contained, there is firt the Omentum,
The Omentum. placed immediately under the Peritoneum, its ue is to increae the heat of the Stomach; this being taken away, the Ventricle and Intetines appear. The Ventricle is an Organic Part ituated immediately under the Diaphragm in the Epigastrium, The Stomach. it is the Intrument of Chylification; it hath two Orifices, the firt is in the upper part of it, and is called the Stomach; this when the Food is taken in, remains hut, that o Fumes and Vapours may not fly up, and o diturb and molet the Head. The
Lower Orifice is called Pylorus, it remains hut till the Food aumed be concocted; it is alo hut when we vomit.The Intetines. The Intetines or Guts have many Anfractus or Bendings, leat the Aliment contained in them hould pas away before a perfect Concoction be made; they have three Tunics and Fibres of all kinds, they are ix in number, the Duodenum, the Jejunum, the Coecum, the Ileon, the Colon, and the Rectum. The next Part we are to take notice of, is the Meentery, in which are the Meeraic Veins and Arteries, the Lactean Veins, and everal Glandules.

Having taken off thee Parts, The Pancreas. the Pancreas or Sweet-bread, becomes apparent, and in it is the Pancreatic Duct and Succus Pancreaticus, found out by Regnerus De-Graaf, a late French Phyician, who held this to be the Seat of Agues, or intermitting Feavers, that the Minera of that Ditemper, which is called,The Caue of Agues. Opprobrium Medicorum, the Digrace of the Phyicians, is there to be found, viz. When this Acid Liquor
is vitiated, and the Lateral Ducts of the Pancreas • opt • ,Franci. De La Boe Sylvius. by ome pituitous or flegmatic and vicid Matter, there adhereing, cauing hereby a tagnation of that Juice, and o a more violent effervence and tendency to a far greater and corroding Acidity. Thus much for the Organs of the firt Concoction, which is Chylification. We come now to thoe of the econd, viz. Sanguification, and among thee the Liver was commonly reputed to be chief;The Liver its Figure and Connexion. this is ituated on the right Side of the lower Venter, jut under the Diaphragm; it is connected by three trong Ligaments. Firt to the Abdomen, by the Vena mbilicalis, which in the adult waxes dry and degenerates into a Ligament. The Second to the Diaphragm on the right Side, by a broad thin Membraneous Ligament from the Peritoneum, which is called Ligamentum Supenorium. The Third alo to the Diaphragm on the left Side, by another round and trong Ligament; its ubtance is red and
oft, like concreted Blood; hence it is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , Mans Liver is very like the Liver of an Oxe or Cow, and doth differ from it neither in conitence, colour, nor tate; whence our Fleh alo is far more imilar to the Fleh of thoe Animals than to the Fleh of Swine. It is from hence the Veins are aid to derive their Origin, becaue the dipered Roots of the two greatet Veins, viz. Cava and Porta eem to be fatened there; tho the Lactean are thought to arie from the Pancreas, and the Vena Arterioa doth really proceed from the Heart: The true ue of the Liver is not to be the Organ of Sanguification, as everal Reaons and late Dicoveries manifet, but as Pecquet aith, it doth percolate and ecern the Bile from the Blood,Its ue to Secern the Bile. as the Spleen doth an Acid Juice, and as the Reins the eroe Part thereof. The manner how this is done, is well explained by Doctor Charleton in his Oeconomia Animalis; it alo affords heat to the Stomach, to concoct the contained Aliment.
It doth likewie eperate from the Blood and aquoe, or watry humour, by a kind of filtration.

It helps to concoct the Lympha, To concoct the Lympha, and impregnate it with a Volatile Salt, &c. and impregnate it with a Volatile Salt and Acid Spirit, drawn forth out of the Nutriment; hence when this Part is evilly affected, a Dropie will enue. Dr. Francicus De La Boe Sylvius will have it not to eparate but joyn together Humours; not to ecern, but to mix and unite; but this is no better than ficticious. On the right and concave part of the Liver, there are two Meatus's for the receiving the two orts of Bile, the Veicula Bilaria, and the Porus Bilarius, the Veicula Bilaria, Folliculus Fellis, Its Ducts and Meatus's. or < in non-Latin alphabet > , is an Oblong Veel in the hape of a Pear; it hath two parts, Fundus and Cervix, it lies under the Vena Porta, receives the thinner Bile, and exonerates into the Intetines: This is the Balom of the Blood, as Helmont calls it, and it is this that renders the Feces fluxible.

The Porus Bilarius, is an Oblong
Veel ariing from the Liver, it is united with the Meatus Syticus into the Ductus Communis, this transfers the groer and thicker part of the Bile.

In the left Hypochondrium is placed the Spleen;The Slpeen. Inects want a Spleen, and thoe Creatures that have no Bladder; as a Chameleon and many others; and it is a fale Aertion, Habte & Muca Splenem. It hath often been taken out of Dogs and Cats, without any great detriment to them, or peril of Life; for then the Pancreas upplies its defect: It hath many Fibres woven together, after a wonderful contexture, to confirm and trengthen the lax, pongy, and paremchymous ubtance of it, leat it hould be broken by the impule of the Blood flowing from the Arteries; alo, that hereby it may be able to contract it elf, and compres the Blood that is in its lax Cavities into the Vena Splenica, and o help the Pule of the Arteries.Its ue. Its ue is not to ecern the Melancholy Homours from the Blood, as the Ancients held; neither is the Opinion of Van Helmont
probable, Helmont's Opinion fale. who detin'd it to more noble Actions; namely, to be the • eat of his Archeus, and the immediate Organ of the Senitive Soul, and to determinate the Actions of the Vital Soul, reident in the Stomach, and o the Seat of the Intellect, in which Conceptions are formed of Sleep and Dreams, of Venery, and of divers Dieaes; which to others are evident to be the effect of the Brain and the Thorax; as an Atma, a Pluriie, an Apoplexy, an Epilepie, a Vertigo, and an Incubus. But the true Opinion of its ue, is that of Waleus,
Waleus the the Inventer of its true Function. grounded on Autopy, and certain Reaons, which is, that it doth receive the more Acid part of the Blood, no otherwie than we ee an Acid Spirit eperated from Things by a Chymic Ditillation. This Acid Liquor (which you may, if you pleae, call Melancholy) is mingled with the Blood in its Veels, and with the Chyle, to attenuate and make them more dilute; whence the Spleen being once obtructed, there doth preently enue a coacervation of gros Humours in the
Body; not becaue thee Cras Humours are not drawn from the Blood by the Spleen, but becaue the Spleen cannot communicate that attenuating Acid Liquor to the Blood and Chyle; what of this Acid Liquor is unprofitable for Nutrition, is excerned by Urine. We come now to the Reins or Kidneys,The Reins. They have their Situation under the Liver and Spleen, near the Spine, upon the Mucles of the Loins; they have two Caruncles like Glandules, thro which the Serum of the Blood is cribrated, and two Venters, one at the end of the Emulgent Veins, and another at the Origin of the Ureters, its ue is to eperate the ero • part of the Blood, and evacuate it thro the Ureters into the Bladder, and thence thro the Meatus rinarius. To the exterior Membranes of the Reins, do adhere two mall Veels, called, Capulae Atrabilariae; The ue of the Capulae Atrabilariae. thee receive a cras, excrementitious, and biloe Humour, eperated from the Blood, either by the Liver, Heart, or
Spleen; but more epecially, that which is elaborated in the Spleen, and is here reconded, being not able to penetrate the angut Paages of the Reins. Hence Urines do look black, when thee Veels are too replete; where often is the Seat of ome Morbific Caue, epecially in Melancholy Effects.The Ureters. The Ureters are long Veels or Channels, ariing from the Reins, implanted into the Bladder; they are commonly two in number. Riolan relates he aw two on each ide of a Woman, that had the Venereal Ditemper. Solomon Albertus takes notice of one that had three on one ide and but one on the other. I my elf aw a Woman opened at St. Thomas's Hopital, who had two Ureters on one Side, having two ditinct Originations in the Kidneys, and were alo in two ditinct places inerted into the Bladder, one in the Neck of it, and the other in the Fundus; thee are often obtructed by Stones and Gravel, and very acute Pains are hereby created.The Bladder. The Bladder or
Veica rinaria, is ituated in the Hypogatrium, between the two Tunics of the Peritoneum, in that Cavity that is made by the Os Sacrum, Coxendicis and Pubis, as in a proper Venter and eperate Abdomen; it hath a Contrictive orbicular Mucle in the Neck of it, called Sphincter, An experiment touching the Coction of a Humane Bladder, with ome Liquors. which hinders the involuntary emiion of Urine, Borrichius oberved of the Bladder, this curioity, That if it be boiled in Acid Things, it preently turns to a Mucilage or Jelly; if in Salt Things it is incraated; in Oleaginous Things, as alo in Liquors that have an Alkali in them, a • Salt of Tartar, or incinerated Herbs, it is neither incraated, nor turned to a Mucilage; but is burnt up as if it were laid upon live Coals, and quikly is worn to Power; from which it is apparent with how much peril to the Bladder, either Acid Salt or Oleaginous Things are injected to diolve or break the Stone.The Veels and Organs of Generation; why we omit initing on them. We hould now come to the Spermatic Veels, and the Organs of Generation,
but modety will not permit me to expoe them to the captious and ignorant Vulgar in their Native Language; thinking it no way convenient that thoe empty Heads that have not arrived to that mall degree of Literature, as to read a Latine or Greek Author, hould in their Mother Tongue have a propect of thoe Things which both Nature and Reaon endeavour to conceal from uch hallow brain'd Medicators; I mean thoe Pretenders, who tile themelves the Sons of Art; and make their brags that they have acended to the very top and < in non-Latin alphabet > of this Noble Faculty; when alas no Name becomes them o well as Quacks and Emperics, who have pickt a few blind Recipe's out of ome illy pedantic Tranlation, uch forooth as Culpepper, that Stargazing Atrologic Coxe-comb, who laughs at Learning, derides the Works of all the Grave and Learned Men, and Nick-names our ablet Phyicians, or The Author of, Little Venus Unmasked, or the Pocky Doctor. See his Reflections on everal of the worthy Members of the Colledge of Phyicians, in the Lord Moons Cae. Gideon Harvey, that conceited Emperic,
or that illiterate Peudochymit, the Author of Medela Medicina. But I hall refer the intelligent Reader to the Learned Treatie of De Graaf de Organis Virorum & Mulierum.

We come then now to the Middle Region of this Microcom, the middle Venter or Cavity, which is called the Thorax or Breat:The middle Venter or the Thorax. this is all that Cavity that is circumcrib'd above by the Clavicles, below by the Diaphragm, before by the Sternum, and on both Sides by the Ribs; as the lower Venter contains the Natural Parts, o this contains the Vital. The Parts of this are either the Containing or the Contained, and thee are either Common or Proper; the Common are the ame with thoe of the Lower Venter; the Proper Parts are the Mammae Papps or Breats, the Diaphragm, the Pleura and the Mediatinum. The Contained are the Vicera and Vaa; the Vicera are the Heart with the Pericardium, the Lungs and part of the Apera Arteria. This Venter hath 44 Mucles,
to guard and defend it, and to dilate and contract the Breat, 22 on each ide, of which 11 are external, 11 internal.

The Mammae or Breats,The Breats and their Parts. are placed in the middle of the Thorax, under the Pectoral Mucle, both for their vicinity, and nearnes to the Heart, that Fountain of Heat; for the convenience of giving Suck, and for the adding to the Beauty and Pulchritude of the Body. I peak of the Mammae of the Female Sex, they are carce perceptible in thoe that are young, but when the Natural Heat of the Body hath obtained a due augmentation and begins to invigorate the Parts of the Body, then thee begin to tumify at the ame time when the Mentruums begin to flow: In Old Women they grow flaccid and nothing apparent but the very Nipple, the Fat and Glandules being all conumed. The parts of this are the Papilla and the Mamilla: the Papilla is an extuberance in the Center of it, called the Nipple, the ends of the Nerves and Arteries
do concenter in it; which is apparent from its exquiite Sene and Red Colour: Hence it is compared to the Glans of the Penis, for it may be erected by Contact and Suction; and doth afterwards become flaccid. Cancers, and other Tumors about this part, by Chyrurgeons are determined to be pernicious. Hyppocrates tells us, That if in a Woman with-child, her Nipples turn upwards it is a Male, if downwards a Female, that he bears; but the confeion of Women hath not yet confirmed it: It hath a Circle round about it, called Areola, which in Virgins is of a pale Colour, in thoe that are big and give Suck brown; in Old Women black. It hath many little perforatons in the middle, for the Milk to come forth; its ue is to enter the Mouth of the Infant, that it might uck: There is alo a titillation in it, whereby Mothers and Nures, by a pleaing kind of tickling, and ome ene of pleaure, are inticed to exhibit their Breats to the Infant.

The Mamilla is all that part beide the Nipple that welleth and rieth above the circumjacent; it hath many Glandules; which in Virgins are more hard; in thoe that are big and give Suck, they are more welled; their ue is for the preparation of Milk, there is a great conent between thee and the Womb; hence as oon as ever the Infant is Born, the Blood is no longer carried to the Womb, but to the Breats, and thence Milk is generated; hence thoe that give Suck have very eldom their Monthly Terms; and ometimes the Children draw forth Blood intead of Milk; yea, which is matter of greatter admiration, the Mentruous Blood ometimes hath been oberved to come from the Breats, and Milk carried thro the Womb, and thence evacuated: How Milk is generated, it is not eay to determine, and I will not tay here to debate the Controvery; whether it is carried with the Blood by the Thoracic Arteries,Some Conjectures how Milk is generated. and ecern'd there-from by the Glandules of the Mammae, or whether the
Chyle acends to the Breat thro the Milky Veins from the Meentery, or whether, as the Learned Dr. Wharton thought, a peculiar Juice drawn from the Nerves, and added to the Chyle, doth make Milk. The ue of the Mammae firt is to be a defence to the Heart, hence Men of a Colder and more Effeminate Contitution, have great Breats, and Women that are almot de •• itute of them, have Manlike Voices: Secondly, They erve for the Generation, Segregation, or Depuration of the Milk for the Nutrition of the Infant: Thirdly, For the Adorning and Beautifying the Body.

The Diaphragm is the partition between the Lower and Middle Venters,The Diaphragm it is a ingular Mucle of a different Figure and Action from all the ret; its Situation is tranvere, and omething oblique, declining downwards; its Figure is circular, its Subtance flehy, but in the middle nervous and membranous; for the Center appears to be a thin Skin and a nervous Circle
intead of a Tendon; if this be wounded, Death enues. The ue of this is to caue a free repiration, to help the Mucles of the Abdomen in the expulion of Excrements and the Foetus, to promote the ditribution of the Chyle, to ditinguih the Vital Parts from the Natural; to which ome add that this is the Seat of Laughter, becaue the Nerves of the Diaphragm have everal ramifications in the Mucles of the Lips and the Cheeks; hence in the percuion of that part, the Mucles of the Face being contracted, and Lips with the Cheeks moved, Laughter arieth;The Caue of Sardonian Laughter. but this is not true Laughter, but only that which is called Rius Sardonius: for the Spleen is the proper Seat of Laughter, according to that Ditich:
Cor ardet, Pulmo loquitur, Fel commovet Iras,
Splen ridere facit, cogit amare Jecur.
The Heart doth burn, the Lungs do peak, the Gall doth Anger move,
The Spleen doth laugh, the Liver tirs up Love.
Hence Melancholy and Splenetic Perons are more prone to laugh than others.

In the fore-part of the Chet is the Sternum, at the end of which is the harp pointed Cartilage, called Cartilago Eniformis, and on both ides are placed the Ribs,The Ribs. which are commonly twelve on each ide. Melancton aith that Adam had thirteen, but it is greatly to be quetion'd. Fallopius aith he aw two everal times thirteen, and Riolan once. The upper even are called Verae, true Ribs, becaue they reach the Sternum; the five lower ones are called Nothae, or Batard Ribs, becaue of their hortnes.

The Pleura is a thin Skin inveting the inward parts of the Middle Region,The Pleura the Seat of the Pleuriie. as the Peritoneum doth the Lower; this is that part that is affected in the Pleuriie, tho Late Writers demontrate
that the effect of this part doth only econdarily happen in that Peracute Ditemper.

The Mediatinum is a Skin of the ame kind, The Mediatinum. dividing the Cavity of the Thorax and the Lungs into two ditinct parts. To this is joyned the Thymus in the Throat or upper part of the Thorax, between the diviion of the Subclavian Veins and the Arteries; this is of a glandulous, pongy, oft, and white Subtance in Children newly born it is ditinguiht by a three-fold and large Glandule, but in the adult it is extenuated by heat for want of moiture: Its ue is to be a prop to the Veels that acend by it, viz. the Vena Cava, the great Artery, and their branches preading into the Arms and Scapulae, and to defend them let they hould be hurt by attaching the Bone. The Pericardium,
The Pericardium. otherwie the Chamber Chet, or Pannicle of the Heart, is a Membrane incompaing the whole Heart; o far ditant from it as may uffice for its motion, and the containing that Liquor which is found
within its cavity. Its ue is to be the Domicil of the Heart, and to contain in it a Whey and Watery Liquor, not unlike Urine, to moiten and refrigerate the Heart, and o render its motion more facil:Whence proceeded that Water that iued out of our Saviours ide. This is that Liquor that came forth out of the Side of out Bleed Savior; when pierced, mixed with Blood; for it is aid, Out of his Side came forth Water and Blood.

The Heart is one of the principal Parts of an Animal,The Heart. It is not ituated in the left ide as oine imagine. the Fountain of Life; it is ituated in the middle of the Body, that o the Blood and Spirits might fitly be ditributed thro the whole Body; it is of every ide encompaed by the Lungs, yet its Motion is perceived mot on the left Side.

1t Becaue the great Artery is on that Side,The reaon why it beats more on the left ide, than on the right. and the Cavity of the left Ventricle far exceeds that of the right, and in this the Vital Spirit is contained: Hence it is vulgarly reputed, altho erroneouly, That the Heart hath its reidence on the left Side, and ome Practitioners apply Cordial Epithems only to the left Side.

2dly, The Vena Cava being on the right Side, and there acending thro the Thorax, the Heart cannot conveniently decline that way. It is of a Conic Figure, the upper part is called the Bais or Radix of it, the lower Mu • ro, Vertex, Apex, or the Cone of the Heart; its primary Action is to be the Fountain of Heat: this is manifet by that Dieae called a Syncope and other defects of the Heart, where its Heat is intercepted: for then the Members of the Body detitute, do faint and loe their brisk Activity, wherewith they were before actuated. Hence Cordials profit in uch Affects;How Cordials help the Heart in Syncope's. by exciting the almot extinguiht Heat; and tirring up the drooping Spirits; this Heat is not caued only by the Motion of the Heart, as the Car • e • ians ay it is; for there is implanted Heat in the Heart, before its Motion, and Motion is only the Preerver, and not the Producer of Heat in the Heart: but this Heat is excited by an Ebullition, whereby the Blood dilating it elf, requires a more
ample pace; and o breaks forth, jut as the mixture of Lime and Water produces an Ebullition; and Flower of Brimtone mingled with Spirit of Turpetine; and Salt of Tartar with Aqua fortis caues a great Fervecency. 3dly. Another great ue of the Heart, is to turn Chyle into Blood, to be the Organ of Sanguification, and to perfect and renew the depauperated Blood, that returns in the Veins in its Circulation. Another ue of it, is to move continually: Hence it keeps the Blood from Putrefaction, makes it more elaborate, kindles that Vital Flame that's in it, and diperes it as a Nutriment adapted to every part.

This Motion is called the Pule,The Pule. which is continual and never ceaing, tirred up by the Blood flowing into it, and the Pulive Faculty reident therein; this conits of Sytole, Diatole,
Its Sytole, Diatole, and Periytole. and Periytole. Sytole the proper and natural motion of the Heart, is a Contraction of it into a narrow compas, that o the contained Blood might be forc'd from
the right Ventricle thro the Arterial Vein into the Lungs, and from the left thro the Arteria Aorta into the whole Body. The Diatole, which is Accidentary, and not o properly called a Motion as the Sytole, becaue it is a Paion rather than an Action; is a Dilatation of the Heart, that it might draw in the Blood thro the Vena Cava into the right Ventricle, and thro the Arteriae Venoa into the left.
Periytole is the pace of ret between the two preceding Motions.
In every Sytole the Heart doth plentifully receive the Blood, and in every Diatole it plentifully expels it.

After Dr. Harvey had found out the Circulation of the Blood, laying down uch evident and infallible Demontrations as compell'd all to believe it, yet many ignorant of the Fabric and Motion of the Heart, thought that a few Drops, a Scruple or a Dram at the mot of Blood, was thrown out of the Heart at every Pule, and o imagined
that the Mas of Blood in the Body is many hours, yea ome days, circulating thro the Body. Yet I mut acknowledg my Self to be a Proelyte of that Learned and Famous Phyician Dr. Lower,
Dr. Lower De Corde. who hath wrote an Excellent Book of the Heart, and alo of Exquiite Dr. Charleton, The Circulation of the Blood. the Author of Oeconomia Animalis, That the whole Mas of Blood, doth not only once or twice, but very often pas thro the Heart in the pace of an hour. For if we compute how much Blood flows into the Ventricles of the Heart when it is dilated, how much emptied out of it when it is contracted, how many Pules there are in an hour, how much Blood there is contained in the whole Body, we hall eaily evince this Aertion; for by Autopy it appears, and by the experience and tetimony of Renowned Harvey, that in a Healthful Man the left Ventricle of the Heart will at once contain two Ounces, and o much is thrown out at every Sytole; and that there are Two thouand Pules in the
pace of an hour, which is the leat Computation of all; for Waeleus and Regius, have numbred Three thouand, and in ome Four thouand, Plempius 4450, Slegelius 4876, Rolfincius 4420, and Bartholine on his own Writ 4400. tho thee differ according to the Age, Temperament and Diet, &c. And uppoe that in a Man there are Twenty five Pounds of Blood, which is a greater quantity than is granted either by Nature or Anatomits; for the quantity of Blood contained in a Humane Body, eldom exceeds Twenty five pound, and is eldom under Fifteen: If we uppoe two Ounces of Blood received and thrown out at every Pule, and Two thouand Pules in an hour,How often the Blood circulates thro the Body in an hour. the number of Ounces that pas thro the Heart in that pace, make up Three hundred thirty two pound: Hence it necearily follows, that the whole Mas of Blood circulates thro the Body thirteen times every hour; but eeing o great a quantity of Blood is eldom found in the Body of a ound Man,
and o few pules in the pace of an hour,Vid. Dr. Lower de Corde. it is very congruous to reaon that the Blood paes thro the Heart more than Thirteen Times in an hour.

At the Bais of the Heart there are two Procees called Anricula, their ue is to receive the Blood and Air, leat it uddenly ruh into the Heart and caue a Suffocation; there are alo on both ides two large Cavities, which are called the Ventricles of the Heart, of which the right receives the Blood from the Vena Cava to upply the Lungs and ends it into the left Ventricle, to make the Vital Spirit and Arterial Blood of that Blood prepared in the right Ventricle and tranmitted thro the Septum and the Lungs, and of the Air drawn in thro the Mouth and Notrils prepared in the Lungs and ent thro the Arteria Venoa with the Blood into the left Ventricle of the Heart. The ue of both thee Ventricles is to generate and perfect the Arterial Blood, to receive the Venal Blood, make it more perfect, and expel it thro the
Arteries into the extreme parts of the Body, and that they may thereby be nourih'd. Between thee two Ventricles there is an Intertitium or Partition, called Septum; it hath everal Meanders, Caverns, Windings and Perforations in it, to admit the thinner part of the Blood from the right into the left Ventricle of the Heart.

The Heart hath many Veels,The Veels belonging to the Heart. the chief are the Vena Cava, and the Vena Arterioa inerted in the right Ventricle, and the Arteria Venoa and Arteria Magna in the left Ventricle; oppoite to which, within the Ventricles, there are eleven Valves or little Doors, which when they are open receive the Blood, when hut, top it from coming back again. The Vena Cava hath a membraneous Circle at its Orifice to trengthen the Heart, which is divided into three membraneous Valves; called, Tricupides. The Vena Arterioa, alo hath three Valves, which united, give the imilitude of a Bihops Mitre. The Arteria Magna, likewie
hath three Valves, like thoe in the Vena Arterioa exactly hut, called alo Sigmoides.

The Lungs,The Lungs are divided into the right and left part by the Mediatinum, that o when one part is hut, the other might perform its Office; both thee parts are ubdivided into two Lobes about the fourth Vertebra of the Thorax, the upper of which is horter than the lower; their ubtance is lax, pongy, and oft, that they may eaily be extended and receive the Air.

Their ue.Their ue is to ventulate and refrigerate the Heart, and free it from that fuliginous excrement which it carries off with the Blood, thro the Vena Arterioa; it exhibits Breath to Men to make, an articulate Voice, and to Brutes to make an inarticulate one: Sylvius addeth, that it condeneth the Air taken in, and o repreeth the rarified Blood in the right Ventricle of the Heart, and o hereby doth allay the aetuation that is excited in it; but this is as much as to ay, the Air taken in doth temperate the heat of the
Heart, Dr. Henhaw's Aero-Chalinos. which is no more than hath been acknowledged by Sylvius's Predeceors. Pecquet will have its ue to be to ditribute the Chyle and detrude it into the Intetines and Lactean Veins; but Dr. Henhaw, no contemptible Author, a Member of the Royal Society, aith, That the principle ue of repiration is, to be intead of a tonic Motion to free the Lungs from Blood, whereby they would be overflown, did they not drive it back again to the Heart, as the tonic Motion doth in all the mucular parts of the Body.

The Fitula Pulmonum,
The Apera Arteria. Apera Arteria, Trachaea, or Wind-pipe, is carried treight from the Mouth to the Lungs thro the Neck, and at the fourth Vertebra of the Thorax, is divided into two parts, both of which enter into the Lungs; thoe are alo ubdivided into two more, and thee again into two others, till at lat, at the uperfice of the Lungs, they end in very mall ramifications. The lower part of the Apera Arteria is called Bronchus, the
upper Larynx; it is inveted with a two-fold Membrane, the one External the other Internal; it erves both for Inpiration and Expiration, to receive and let out the Air as thro a Pipe.

The Larynx, its Mucles. The Larynx, or the Head of this, is the proper intrument of Voice, its Figure is almot circular; it hath thirteen Mucles, four common and nine proper. The firt pair of the common is called Sternothyroides from the Sternum, the econd pair Hyothyroides, which hath its Origination from the Os Hyoidis, the firt pair of the proper is called Crycothyroides, or rather Thyrocricoides. The econd pair Crycoaritenoides poticum. The third pair Ctycoaritenoides laterale, the fourth pair Thyroarytenoides; and the ninth Mucle Arytenoides; the Cartilages of the Larynx are five, the firt is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Scutiformis, the econd < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Annularis, becaue it is round like a Ring; the third and fourth, which ome make but one, is called < in non-Latin alphabet > or Guttalis; it hath two procees in its uperior
part, which joyned together make a little Rimula to modulate the Voice, which by ome is called the little Tongue or Glottis; the fifth is called Epiglottis, which huts the Larynx, that o the Meat and Drink may decend the right way: In the upper part of the Larynx there are two Glandules called the Tonils,The Tonils. which are of a pongy ubtance to receive the moiture of the Brain and convert it into Spittle; whereby the Fauces, the Larynx, the Tongue and the Oeophagus are humected: Dr. Wharton aigns more noble ues to them, viz. To be the Organs of Tate, and to promote the Concoction of the Ventricle, by a kind of fermentative Vertue, becaue they contract Acidity; but the Tip of the Tongue tates before gutible Objects reach the Tonils, and when thee are evilly affected the Tate remains alo, when thee are inflamed the Stomach nevertheles doth concoct. At the lower end of the Larynx there are other Glandules, called by Dr. Wharton Thyroides, on both ides one, thro
which the Veins are dieminated from the extern jugular; their ue is to irrigate the Larynx, with a fat and vicous, not fluid Humidity, that the Cartilages might • o more apt to move; and the Voice become weeter; Hence Women have a clearer Voice than Men,Why Women have clearer Voices than Men. becaue in them thoe Glandules are larger, and o afford more of this oleaginous and mooth moiture: As the Apera Arteria
• s the Pipe of the Lungs, o the Oe • phagus is the Pipe of the Ventricle or Stomach; its beginning is at the Mouth, where it is called Pharynx; and hence it decends treight to the Ventricle under the Wind-pipe, it conits of three Tunics, it hath four Mucles, the firt is called Oeaphagus, the econd Sphenoparyngeus, the third Stylopharyngeus, the fourth Cephalopharyngeus; by thee Mucles is perform'd Deglution or Swallowing, which is the proper Act of the Oeopha • s.

An appendix to the middle Venter is the Neck,The Neck. which is a medium between the Thorax and the Head,
its ue is to erve the Oeophagus, the Wind-pipe and the Lungs: Hence thoe Animals which want Lungs as Fih, alo want a Neck; it alo affords Nerves to the foreparts, as the Shoulders, the Cubits, the Hands, and the Diaphragm; for thoe Creatures that want thee Parts have no Neck. Thus we have briefly delineated the parts of the two lower Regions of the Body, namely, the Abdomen and the Thorax; we come now to view the upper which is the Head.

The upper Venter, or the Head its Diviion.It is divided into two parts Capillata and Facies; Capillata is that part upon which Hairs do grow, the fore part of which is called Synciput, from the Frons to the Coronal Suture; the hinder Part is called Occiput, from the beginning of the Sutura Lambdoides to the firt Vertebra of the Neck; the middle Part between thee which is Gibboe is called Vertex, the lateral Parts between the Eyes and the Ears are called Tempora, the Temples; the uperior part of the Face
is called Frons. The Inferior Parts are the Eyes; the Noe, the Ears and the Mouth, in whch is contained the Tongue and other Parts.

The Pericranium and Periotium.We hall begin with the Pars Capillata, or hairy Part of this Venter; the extern Membranes of this are two, the Pericranium and the Periotium, which encompas the Cranium. The inward Membrances, which encloe the Brain under the Cranium, are the Dura Mater and the Pia Mater;
The Dura Mater and Pia Mater. the Dura Mater, o •
Cara Menynx, divides the Cerebrum from the Cerebellum, and the Brain into its right and left Parts, and o contitutes four Sinus's o • Ventricles, the receptacles of Blood and Spirits; beides thee four Sinus's there are three more, one at the bottom of the Calx the other two lateral ones. Their ue is to receive the Arterial Blood,The Ventricles of the Brain. which is uperfluous in the Nutrition of the Brain, and the generation of Animal Spirits; and from thee proceeds that Blood that is evacuated at the Notrils.
The outward part of the Brain is called Cortex, the inward Medulla. The Cortex is oft but of on Ah Colour, which ome think arieth from the innumerable Veins there dieminated; the Medulla is more hard and compact of a white Colour; it hath two Parts, the one Globoe, which hath three Cavities or Ventricles, the other Oblong, called Medulla Oblongata, where is the fourth Ventricle, in which the Animal Spirits are generated; and here is the Origen of all the Nerves; as this Part decends down to the Spine, o it is called, Medulla Spinalis.

The Motion of the Brain, coniting of a Sytole and Diatole. The Brain is oberved by ome to have a Motion coniting of a Sytole and Diatole, in its Diatole or Dilatation it draws in the Vital Spirits, with the Arterial Blood and Air thro the Notrils: In its Sytole or Contraction, it forceth the Animal Spirits, therein elaborated, into the Nerves.

The Cerebellum hath the ame Subtance, Colour, Motion, and Ue, with the Cerebrum, only it hath everal circular Gyrations
in an exact Order, which the Cerebrum hath not; it hath two Procees, called, Proceus vermi-formes, whoe ue is, that the Calamus Script • rius, being pres'd by the Cerebellum, might not be obtructed thereby.
The other Parts oberved in the Brain, are the Rete Mirabile, the Glandula Pituitaria, the Infundibulum, the Corpus Calloum, the Fornix, the Plexus Choroides, the Glandula Pinealis, &c.

The Rete Mirabile, or Plexus Retiform • s, is at the Bais of the Cerebrum; it conits of Carotid and Cervical Arteries, brought up from the Heart to the Bais of the Brain, and bring in them Blood and Vital Spirits to this Rete, for the firt preparation of the Animal Spirits.

The Glandula Pituitaria.The Glandula Pituitaria, is of a harder and more compa •• Subtance than other Glandules, it receives the Excrements of the Brain thro the Infundibulum, and throws them out upon the Palate.

The Infundibulum.The Infundibulum is an Orbicular Cavity, made of the Pia-mater; it
hath four little Channels, aith Riolan, which ditil the flegmatic Serum thro their four Foramina, or little Perforations; it hath two Glandules or Protuberances of the Brain, thro which the Infundibulum receives the Serum from the Ventricles; they do alo top and impede the great Impule of that Matter that is carried to the Infundibulum, leat it hould thereby be too much dilated or broken.

The Corpus Calloum.The Corpus Calloum is in the Medulla of the Brain, where its Subtance is harder, and where the two anterior Ventricles make two Extuberances; it is ditinguiht by a thin lax, and wrinkled Membrane, called, Septum Lucidum, becaue when extended and expoed to the Light it is Pellucid, the inferior white part of it, where the two Ventr •••• are joyn'd together is of a triangular Figure.

Between the firt Ventricle and the Fornix,
The Plexus Choroides is formed the Plexus Choroides, its Contexture is of Veins and Arteries, its ue is the ame with the Rete Mirabile.

The Glandula Pinealis its ue. The Glandula Pinealis, is a Glandule of a conic Figure, it is called by the Greeks < in non-Latin alphabet >
Conarion, by others the Penis of the Brain, its ue is the ame with that of the other Glandules, but epecially to ditribute the Veels of the Brain.

Cartes and his Followers imagined the Soul to reide in this part of the Brain. Carteius and his Followers, Regius; Hogelandus, and Meyonierius, ay, that this Glandule being placed in the middle of the Ventricles, which are always ditended with Spirits, doth receive the Motion of all Objects, and the Soul being placed here, doth by thee Motions apprehend all enible Species, or rather external Idea's, which proceed from the five Senes, and as it were in the Center of them, dicerns them all; and then by the help of this it ends the Spirits to the Nerves, jut as all things that are conpicuous in a large Field, are in their Order repreented in a little Spheric Looking-glas. This therefore, according to Cartes, is the common Seat of Sene and Imagination; but becaue many of the Carteian Sentiments of the Soul
contrary to our Hypotheis depend upon the verity of this Aertion, I hall here take occaion to manifet the fality of it: For
1. This is too exile and obcure a Body to repreent the Species of all things clearly,Eight Reaons why it cannot be the Seat of the Soul. for the Species of one thing would impede and hinder the Species of another, it being of too mall a Magnitude, and therefore the Carteians being concious of this, to make their Hypotheis more plauible, make it a great deal bigger in their Cutts and Pictures than really it is.
2. The Species of all the Senes cannot arrive hither, becaue the Nerves do not touch this Glandule.
3. It is ituated in the place of Excrements, where they are excern'd thro the third and the two anterior Ventricles; and certainly here the Species would be greatly contaminated, which Le Forge a Carteian is forc'd to grant.
4. There then would be a great Confuion of different Ideas in this Corpucle, for the Species mut remain
there, otherwie there would be no Memory.
5. There is no Duct or Paag • from this Glandule to the Nerve • neither any communion with the Nerves of the extern Senes.
6. This Glandule is bigger i • thoe Animals, which the Carteia •
will have to be void of reaon.
7. It is ometimes found to b • full of Sand and little Stones, without any hurt to the Reaon: ometimes it is black and infected, how then can it be capable of performing uch noble Operations.
8. There was never any prope •… Motion een in it but only violen •… either of the whole Brain, its Concuion, or ome extern Flatulencie •… for it wants Mucles, thoe Orga •… of Motion, and it adheres firm •… to the Brain; neither is it fille •… with Spirits, for it is not hollow and thoe Tubili Cerebri, are imaginary things, inviible, and invente •… by them to defend their Hypotheis o fictitious and irrational, th •… the preceding Reaons may uffi •… to convince any judicious Peron

The Forehead and Eye-brows.Having done with the Pars Capillata of the Head, we come to the Pars Glabra, which is the Face; its upper part is called Frons, the Fore-head; the Skin of the Fore-head often moves, for it hath Mucles, which Platerus calls Muculos Significativos, becaue they ignifie the effect of the Mind; thee move the Supercilia or Eye-brows, where they are thicker: Thee Mucles have treight Fibres, and therefore they are not to be cut tranverly by Chirurgeons, leat the elevation of the Eye-brows be hindred, but upwards according to their Longitude.

The Eyes.The Eyes are the Intruments of Sight, made up of Humours, Tunics, Mucles, and other Parts, they are two in Number, their Figure is round, omewat Oblong, like a Bulb, each of them having two Angles, called Acanthi; the one extern the other intern: The Parts are various, both in the Eye and about it, for ome are without the Eye for Defence, as the Palpebrae, the Cilia, the Supercilia, and the
Caruncles in the corners of the Eye. The intern Caruncle, or Punctum Lachrymale, contains a Humidity to moiten the Eye; the extern is called Caruncula innominata, in the mall Angle of the Eye, detin'd, according to Dr. Wharton, for the Expurgation of the Brain, and the Succus Nutritius of the Eyes: The Parts that contitute the Body of the Eyes, are the Adeps, the Mucles, the Veels; the Membranes, and the Humours.

The Adeps or Fat of the Eyes doth help to the Calefaction, Humectation, and more facile Motion of the Eyes, and to make them of equal Figure; the Mucles of a Humane Eye are ix, becaue there are o many different Motions, four right and two circular.
Its Mucles.The firt is called Attolens and Superbus, whereby we look upward.
The Second Deprimens and Humilis, whereby we look downward.
The Third Adducens and Bibitorius, which draws the Eye inwards towards the Noe.
The Fourth Abducens and Indignatorius this turns it outward, and caues that Apect of Envy and Didain.
The Fifth Obliquus, it turns the Eye obliquely downwards, towards the extern Angle.
The Sixth Troclearis, which turns it round towards the inward Angle, found out by Fallopius.
The Veels of the Eye are a Vein from the Jugular Arterie, from the Carotid Branches, Lymphatic Veels, and two Nerves, one the Optic Nerve, the other Oculi Motorius.

Its Tunics, with its Humours.The Tunics of the Eye are the Adnata, which Hypocrates calls the White of the Eye, it ends at the circle of the Iris, and is the outward-mot of all; its joyns the Orbite of the Eye, to the interior Bones, like a Ligament; it hath exquiite Sene, it hath alo Veins and Arteries dipered about it, which are not conpicuous, but in an Efflux of Humours, when they well and become exceeding Red, as in an Opthalmia; of which Effect
this Tunic is the Seat. The next Tunic is called Sclerotica, the Fore-part of which is called Cornea, becaue of its horny Subtance; next to this is the Choroidis, its Fore-part is called vea, perforated for the ingres of Species; the Limb or Border of this hath various Colours, whence it is called Iris, a Rain-bow: The third is Retina, or Amphibletroides; it encompaes the Humour Vitreus and its Tunic; this farther is called Aranea, o •
Chritalloides, the proper Tunic of the Chritalline Humour.
The Vitrea Tunica contains the vitreous Humour, and eperates it from the chrytalline; the Humours of the Eyes are the watry, glaie, and chrytalline.

The Ears.The Ears are the Organs of Hearing, they are either extern or intern; the extern are called Auriculae, they are of a emicircular Figure; the upper part of thee is call'd Pinna or Ala, the lower Lobus, or the Lobe of the Ear; the outward Ambit of the Ear is called Helix or Capreolus, the inward
Scapha or Anthelix, in the midt of it there is a large Cavity by the Meatus Auditorius, where that bitter and yellow Excrement is thrown out; it is called Alvearium: The Auris Interna hath everal Parts contained in the Os Petroum, as the Tympanum, the congenite Air, the Mucles and Veels. In the Concha there are three little Bones, called Malleus, Incus, and S • apes, the Hammer, the Anvil and the Stirrop: Thee are the Proxime Organs of Hearing, which render the Sound ditinct.

The Noe.The Noe is the Organ of the Olfactory Sene; this is alo divided into the intern Part and extern Part, the intern Part hath Bones and Nerves with the Mamillary Procees. The Extern hath an upper Part which is called Dorum, the Ridge of which is called Spina, and a lower part cartilaginous and moveable, called Globulus-Nai, the lateral Parts are called < in non-Latin alphabet >
Pinnae or Alae; it is divided within by its Septum into two Notrils, both which are divided about the
middle into two Parts, the one acends up to Os Spongioum, the other above the Palate into the Jaws: Hence Drink ometimes flows out thro the Notrils.
The caue of Sneezing.The Tunic about the Notrils is from the Dura Mater, of an exquiite Sene, and hence when it is excited it caueth Sneezing.

The lat part belonging to the Head, is the Organ of Tate; viz. The Tongue; but here we are firt to conider, of the extern parts about the Mouth, and the in • ern within it: The extern are the Pomum or Circulus Faciei, under the Eyes between the Noe and the Ears, called alo Pudoris Sedes; the part under this is called Bucca, the extern part of the upper Lip Mytax the cavity in the middle Philtrum.

The Mouth.The Mouth conits of parts partly bony, as the upper and lower Mandible, with the Teeth, and partly flehy, as the Lips, the Mucles of the lips, the Buccae and inferior Mandible: the intern parts contained in the Mouth are the
Gums, the Palate, the vula, the Fauces, the Os Gutturis, or Hyoidis.

The Tongue its Ligament.The Tongue is of a flehly, lax, oft, and pongy ubtance, to receive in and imbibe Sapors; it is tyed down by a trong Ligament, which in very many Chidren newly born, doth o bind the Tongue, that it is a cutom among Midwifes,A pernicious Cutom among ome Midwives. tho a pernicious one, and in no wie to be permitted, to tear it aunder with their Nails, that it might not hinder their ucking and future peaking; but it ought to be done by a Chirurgic Intrument; it hath Veins and Arteries, and alo Nerves, both motory and enitive, and five pair of Mucles.
The Artus.Thus we have endeavoured briefly to run over all the three Venters, we come now to the Artus, which are the Hands and Feet.

The Hand and its parts.A Hand in the ignification of Galen and Hypocrates, is that part from the top of the Shoulders to the extremities of the Fingers, and is divided into the Arm and the Hands, trictly o called, or the
extream Hand: The Arm is again divided into the Humerus or Shoulder and the Cabitus. The Humerus is that part from the top of the Shoulder to the Elbow, and the Cubit is from the flexure or bending of the Elbow to the Writ; the extream Hand is divided into the Carpus or Writ, which is that part between the Cubit and the Palm of the Hand; the Metacarpus, which is that part between the Writ and the beginning of the Fingers, and the Fingers; the intern part of the Metacarpus, is called Vola, or the Palm of the Hand; the extern Dorum, or the Back of the Hand; the Fingers are five, the firt is called Pollex or the Thumb, the econd Index, the third Digitus Medius, the fourth Annularis, the fifth Anricularis.

The Foot with its Parts.The Foot is that part which reaches from the Nates to the extremities of the Toes; and jut as the Hand it is divided into the Femur, the Tibia, and Pes Parva; the Pes Parva is alo divided into Pedius, Metapedius, and the
Toes: As for the Mucles of the Artus, I hall refer the Reader to thoe that treat of them, as Bartholine, Riolan and Spigelius.

Having ended the Diviions of the whole Body, there yet remain ome other things that do repond both the Venters and the Artus, already treated on, and they are the Veins which arie from the Liver, and o anwer to the lower Venter; the Arteries from the Heart, which anwer to the middle Venter; the Nerves from the Head, which erve the upper Venter; and the Bones, which repond to the Artus. But I doubt I have been already too tedious in this Chapter, and therefore I hall at preent omit them; and o, altho omething abruptly, end this Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Humours, Temperaments, and Complexions.
div.p:
HAving thus far done our endeavour in delineating in their proper Colours, thoe things we promied in the Front of Title Page of this Dicoure, now thoe that remain do offer themelves in their propoed Order to our Conideration and Explication, and they are the Humours, Temperaments, Complexions, Sexes, and Ages, of Mankind; to begin with the firt, we hall joyn three of them together; being terms almot of a Synonimous Signification, or at leat their Explications very much depending one upon another; onely firt in a prefatory way let me advertize or re-mind both my elf and the ingenious Reader of the great uefulnes and benefit of the
knowledge of them, that o I may be more diligent in performing my part, and the Reader hereby intigated to give greater attention to what is here expoed to his candid perual.

The great ue and benefit of the knowledge of the Temperament • s.It is not enough to have an Idea in our Head of the olid parts of the Body, in order to a compleat knowledge of that Microcom, but alo it is very requiite to note the fluid parts; and truly the Anatomy of that which ome call the Sanguine Liquor (I mean that fluid Subtance continually circulating thro the Veins and Arteries, and purging it elf thro its proper Emunctories, thoe Veels detin'd for Secretion) is no les conducing to the defence of Humane Sanity, and the retoration of it when its lot, which is the only end apired after by the generous Sons of Aeculapius, thoe tanding Pillars and Columns of the Medicinal Faculty; thoe abolutely neceary Miniters of Nature, and under God preervers of Mankind, in their daily Practice and Labours,
both in their Acts of Charity and Deeds of Mercy; in thoe things for which they only expect a recompence from God, and in thoe for which they are ufficiently gratified by Men: I ay this is no les conducing to the Health of Man than the diection of Bodies. What particular part of Learning can contain in it more, both of profit and pleaure, than to know the Principles or ingredients that compoe this Balom of Life, and to ee what a cloe coherence there is between the Actions both Natural, Vital, and Animal, and Paions, Getures, Habits; the Qualities of the Body, as Heat, Cold, Moiture and Drynes, Colour of the Skin and Hair, and the Temperaments of the Body, and what an intimate dependance they have one upon another; how the Health of Man conits in the regularity and order of the Humours, and Sicknes in their ataxy and irregularity; and how by a propect into the Complexion of a Body, Sicknes impending may be fore-een, and effectual
preervations being in time applied, the fatal end of uch urprizing enemies may eaily be prevented? and certainly the bet method a Phyician can ue to retore a Peron, almot overcome by the aaulting violence of morbific tyranny; either when the Particles of his Blood are violently agitated in a continual Fever, that vehement Conflagration and boiling Ebullition of the Crimon Juice, or when the more olid parts, epecially the Vital and Intetine, are almot drowned, when immered in the deluge of a Dropie, that flood and inundation of watery Humours in the Body, or when by the Obtruction of the Pores, the Gall a feculent and excrementitious part of the Blood, doth regurgitate and mingle it elf with the pure Blood, and hereby contuminate it and give it that unhandome tincture of the Yellow Jaundice: I ay what can be more effectual to rout and profligate thee direful Symptoms, than to reduce the Blood (from the vitiation of which Liquor thee
and a thouand more ad and dangerous effects have their firt rie) to its pritine eucraie, and alo the Humours of the Body to their wonted eutaxie; for Sublata caua tollitur effectus, Take but the Caue away and the Effect oon ceaeth; o that hereby the tate of thoe Bodies o afflicted with thee tormenting Maladies is oon meliorated, a good Criis firt appearing and afterwards Nature having received due and proper Auxilaries from ome of her skilful Miniters (I mean thoe Phyicians (tho no other deerve the Name of Phyicians) that are well skilled in the Complexions and Temperaments of Bodies, and accordingly, Methodically, not Emperically, apply their Remedies) doth throw off that morbific Matter, whereby he had o long been burthened and moleted; upon which all thoe Malidies do like Spectrums vanih and diappear.

The Temperaments,The number of the Temperaments, according to Galen. according to the Opinion of Galen and the Ancients, are Nine; four of which
are imple; as the Hot, the Cold, the Moit, and the Dry Temperament; four compound, Hot and Moit, Hot and Dry, Cold and Moit, Cold and Dry, and one Moderate, which they call Temperamentum
< in non-Latin alphabet > . But our thoughts concerning Heat and Cold, and the other Qualities, cannot but be repugnant to the Opinion of the Ancients, they holding that thee four firt qualities,Gaendus. as they call them, are eential to, and deduced from the four Elements; but we from the Magnitude, Figure, and Motion of Atoms; as Hot or Colorific Atoms, are thoe that are Exile in Magnitude, Sphaericin Figure, and Swift in Motion.What Heat is and what Cold. Cold or Frigorific Atoms, are not o Exile in Magnitude, of a Tetrahedic or Pyramidal Figure, coniting of four Sides or equilateral Triangles, which is a Figure mot oppoite to a Sphere, and they are low in Motion.What we are to undertand by Moiture and Drines. Moiture is but a Species of Fluidity, which conits in the moothnes of the Parts and the interperion of Inanity, for Quick-ilver and melted
Lead are Fluid Bodies, yet not Humid; and Siccity or Drines is a meer Privation of Humidity. I hall not therefore treat of the Temperaments according to thoe Qualities, but according to the number of the Humours; tho there alo we cannot in all things agree with the Ancients, as I hall hereafter declare.

The Temperaments rightly ditinguisht, according to the number of the four Humours.The Humours are four, Blood, Choller, Phlegm, and Melancholy, and in whatoever Perons any of thee Humours are predominant, their Temperament hath its denomination thence; o that from hence we learn that there are four orts of Temperaments.

The Sanguine wherein Blood, the Choleric wherein Choler or Bile, the Phlegmatic wherein Phlegm, the Malancholic wherein Melancholy, hath the predominancy. I hall now lay down the Characters of every of them, whereby any intelligent Peron, by a diligent perual of the following Specimen, and a due reflection upon himelf, may eaily be informed what Contitution,
Temperament, or Complexion he is of; I hall begin with the Sanguine.

The Sanguine Contitution decribed.The Sanguine hath the preheminence before any of the ret; thoe of this Complexion are hot and moit, the habit of their Body is Flehy and well Compact, not Fat neither too Lean; for the heat doth not emaciate and make Lean the Body, being alone predominant, and o conume the Body, but it is qualified with a proportionality of Moiture, which erves for Fuel for the vivifying Heat; neither is the Body made gros and fat by the abundance of Moiture which affords Vapors, by which Fat is generated; it being well tempered with a ufficient quantity of Heat, which diipates the abounding Humidity; the firt of which effects always happens in the Choleric Complexion, which is hot and dry, and the other in Phelgmatic, which is quite contrary to that, viz. Cold and Moit.

The treams of fluid Blood that circulate in the Veins and Arteries, are briskly agitated by the penetrating
particles of Fire; and thee ignite Particles are kept from cauing a Conflagration in the mas of Blood, by the Moiture whereby it is duly moderated, o that the Heat actuates and enlivens the Moiture, and the Moiture upplies the Heat with a ufficient Pabulum; hence for the mot part the Colour of their Face is freh and flourihing, the delicate Sanguine Liquor flowing thro its proper Veels, caueth the Cheeks to be tinctur'd with a Crimon Red; their Hair alo, which is an Excrement reembles the predominant Humour, for it is either of a bright or light Colour, which by its glitering Eradiations, manifets the Body from which it reults to abound with Spirits, or ele it is Red, the very colour of the Humour whereof it is generated. They are very Active, Brisk, Lively, Vigorous, Spirituous, very Cheerful and Merry, and of a miling Countenance, by reaon of Spirits, wherewith they of this Complexion do mot of all abound; their Imagination is very pregnant and comprehenive, becaue
impreions are eaily made upon things that are Moit, tho not o long retained; hence they are very ubject to Oblivion and Forgetfulnes; yet ome do frequently commit Actions which manifet Stolidity, as immoderate Laughing and Impudence, in others too much Bahfulnes, and others Actions of Folly. In Dicoure they are commonly very free and liberal; they have an extraordinary Propenion and Inclination to Love, being very much influenc'd by Venus and Cupid, and have very impetuous deires after Venereal Pleaures, tho not o much as thoe that are Choleric, by reaon of the acrimony of the Seed in that Contitution. They leep indifferently well, not o much as thoe that are Phlegmatic; they are nimble in Motion and Exercie, but oon weary; they have a moderate Appetite, unles Humours abound whereby it is clog'd and atiated, alo a moderate Thirt; their Pule is great, yet low; they have frequent and copious Evacuations
of Blood at Noe in the Haemorrhoids, and Women thro thoe paages which Nature hath detin'd to carry the Superfluity of Humours that abound in that moit Sex in their periodic or monthly Evacuations. Their Urine, as to its quantity, is very copious; as to its quality, it is of a laudible Colour and good Conitency. Their Skin to the touch is hot and oft, their Veels are very large and Veins very conpicuous; they are very ubject to a Plethora, and very obnoxious to Feavers and other Acute Ditempers. Thee are the Signs of the Sanguine Complexion, the next is the Choleric, which is the hot and dry Complexion.

They of this Contitution are always Lean,The Choleric Contitution. Pale, or Yellow, epecially under their Eyes; their Hair is Yellow, imitating the Colour of Bile, •• metimes blackih, where the Choler is more adut; they are oon Bald, by reaon of Siccity, which is here the predominant quality; they are of a harp Wit, very olert and crafty, of an
expedite Ingeny; they are prone to Anger, Fury, Rage, Audacity, Boldnes, Boating, Bragging, and deire of Revenge. They leep very little; they dream of Fires, Burnings, Scoldings, Fightings and Tumults; they have exquiite Sene, and are very quick in Hearing, their Pule is great and quick; they have very little Appetite, ometimes loath eating, epecially in the Summer; they love thoe Meats mot that are cold, but they find great prejudice by fating; they have an inatiable Thirt, and drink frequently; they grow apace and quickly wax Old, becaue their radical Moiture is oon conumed by the abundance of heat; they have a wonderful proclivity to Venery, becaue of the acrimony of their Seed; they are very much injur'd by the immoderate ue of it, becaue their Spirits <> eaily diipated by reaon of their tenuity. They are prone to all biloe Ditempers, as Tertian Agues, Phrenies, Pleuriies, Vomitings, Diarrheas, Eriipala's, Shingles, Puhes and Pimples on their Faces.

The next is the Phlegmatic Contitution; they of this Temperament are Cold and Moit,Signs of the Phlegmatick Temperament. the colour of their Skin is white, they are fat and obee, yet not flehy, their Hair is brown and treight, they are cold to the touch, epecially their Hands and Feet; they have a tollerable Imagination; and indifferent good Perception, but a very hallow Memory; they are dull and blockih, of a very low and obtue Ingeny; they are very placable and oon reconciled, extreamly devoted to leep; they dream of Cold, Waters, Floods, Ponds, Seas, Rain, Snow, Drownings, and white Things; their Pule is little and low; they have a mall Appetite; little or no Thirt; they grow Old very lowly, and have very little Inclination to Venery, but in the moderate ue find much benefit, becaue by tirring up in them the Natural Heat, which is almot Dormant, the Phelgm is concocted, and the Body made more temperate. They are better in fair Weather and always wore in cold and rainy Weather;
the Ditempers •• at they are mot addicted to, are Catarrhs, Coughs, Dropies, Cachexies, Lethargies, Palies, Appoplexies, &c. They excern a cras, white, and inipid Excrement thro the Mouth and Notrils; their Urine is white and thin, and Women of this Complexion are often troubled with that which they call the Whites, which is an efflux of a thin white Humour thro the terus, either continually, or at leat in no Order or certain Period. The lat of the Four Complexions which yet remains is the Melancholic.

How to ditinguish when the Melancholic Humour i • predominant.Thoe of this Contitution are cold and dry; their Colour is brown or omewhat black; they are of a lean habit of Body, their Veins are very treight and narrow their Hair is black, hard, rough, or cras, lowly encreaing and oon hatening to the Canities of Old Age; they are very obnoxious to • ear and adnes, and that ometimes without any known or manifet caue, yet they are prudent cautious, wary, contant and ingenous:
but where this atrabilous Humour is adut, they are treacherous and unfaithful; they are very difficult to be moved to Anger, but when they are, they are almot implacable; they have a very trong Memory, by reaon of Siccity; they are very wakeful, and leep very interruptedly and diquietly; they dream of black Things, Murthers, dead Bodies, Graves and the Devils, &c. They have a very uncertain Apect and ad Countenance; their Pule is tardy and hard; they have for the mot part a good Appetite, becaue of the Acidity of this Humour, which is prepared for the concoction of Food in the Ventricles, and tirring up of Cold; yet ometimes, thro the Vitiation of this Humour, the Appetite is very much dejected; they have but little Thrit, becaue of the Serum and Spittle which abounds in this Contitution; they have often ower Belchings, which arie from thoe Crudities wherewith Melancholy Perons do abound; they are very tardy in the performance of
Venereal Acts, and receive very much injury from the frequent ue of them; yet thoe are more prone to them that abound with Flatulencies, and are hereby often excited to Venereal Actions; they are very ubject to Tumours and hardnees of the Spleen and Hypochondriac Affects, to Tertian Agues, Leproies, Warts and Haemorrhoids, &c. They often vomit and pit frequently: Hence Melancholy Perons are often called Sputatores, they are commonly Cotive, and their Excrements are blackih; they alo avoid black Blood thro the Haemorrhoids; their Urine is thin and white, ometimes cras and livid.

Thus we have given a brief Specimen of the Four Contitutions, let me now ubjoyn that I would not have the Reader think me o much devoted to the trite old Galenic way, as to think that the Blood is a Compoition of thee Four Humours blended together, or that I am o trict a Chymit as to explode and utterly reject the Notion of the Four Humours as a
ueles and unprofitable Fiction, and only adhere to their Doctrine (tho very ingenuous) of the Five Principles: But our Apprehenions are, that tho it be utterly untrue that there are in the Veels Four ditinct Humours,Dr. Catle's Chymical Galenit. for whatoever is contained in the Arteries and Veins, is either the tale deflragrated Blood, or the Alimentary Juice freh come into the Veels, or ele the Serum or Whey returned by the Lymphaducts, or ele ome particles of Nitre, and other Bodies received in by the Lungs and Mouths of the Veins from the Ambient; and tho the Blood differ in everal Bodies, only as to the abundance or defect of Natural Heat, yet Men are not improperly aid to be of a Melancholic, Choleric, or ome other Temperament; inomuch, as by how much the more vigorous or remis the Bowels and Entrails are, by o much the more weakly or powerfully Concoctions are performed,Willis de Fermentatione & Febribus. and conequently the Blood apt to be overcharged with tale and adut,
or ele crude and phlegmatic Excrements, in which the Peron either way dipoed, is not improperly aid to be of a Phlegmatic or Choleric Temper; and if the adut or raw Excrement be not rightly and duly eperated out of the Mas, by the effervecency of the Blood, I ee no reaon why I may not ay, A Man abounds with a Melancholic Phlegmatic or Choleric Humour, and it o, than the Notions about Pharmacy aiming at an evacuation or ele alteration of the Humours, are not framed amis, nor without good reaon; for I uppoe it alters not much the cae as to practice, whether we uppoe there is too great a redundancy of one of the Humours in the Blood, or whether (which is the right Notion) we apprehend the Blood depraved with a phlegmatic or raw Juice, or a biloe Excrement, coniting of Salt and Sulphur, or the Melancholic, in which the Caput Mortuum, or earthy part is predominant; for either of thee Notions will direct us (when the Blood is
unable to fine it elf) to ait it with thoe Alteratives, which time and experience hath recommended to us, as proper in thoe caes; and thoe Purgers which have been long oberved more particularily to make eparation, either of the Pituitous, Choleric, or Melancholic Parts of the Blood; for tho it be irrational to think that Purgers do, with a certain knowledge or choice, lay hold of one Humour rather than another; yet is that ditinction of Purgers into Cholagoga, Phlegmagoga, Melanagoga, and Hydragoga, of very good ue, and founded upon Obervation and Experience; inomuch as the everal Purgers, by cauing very different Fermentations, and variouly agitating the particles of the Blood, may with good reaon caue different Seperations, and o one Purger to evacuate that ort of Excrement, Barm or Lee, which another cannot.

The Doctrine of the Four Humours reconciled with that of the Five Chymic Principles.Thus our Doctrine of the Four Humours, doth not detroy that of the Five Principles; for altho it is
apparent that in the Blood there are five Principles; as

Spirit, which is the Subtile and Volatle part of it, whoe Particles being always expanded, endeavouring to take their flight, do agitate the gros Corpucles of the other Principles, wherein they are ininvolved, and o keep them in that continual Motion of Fermentation,

Sulphur, which is a Principle of a Conitence omewhat more cras than Spirit, and next to it mot active; from this Principle arieth the variety of Colours and Smells, the pulchritude and deformity of Bodies, and the diverity of Tates in a great meaure; that this Principle is copious in the Blood, is evident from this, that we are for the mot part fed with Fat and Sulphurious Things: From the olution of this it is very probable that the Crimon Tincture of the Blood arieth, for ulphureous Bodies do above all others tinge their diolving Mentruums with a red Colour; and when, by reaon of Crudity,
the Sulphur is not diolved, the Blood becomes pale and watery, and will carce make red a Linnen Cloth that is dipt in it. The Mas of Blood thus impregnated, with a coniderable quantity of Sulphur, together with abundance of Spirits, becomes very fermentecible.

Salt (which is a principle of a Nature, more fixt than either Spirit or Sulphur, neither o dipoed for Volatility) is that which makes Bodies compact and olid, alo ponderous and durable; it promotes the coagulation of Bodies and Retards their Diolutions, reits Corruptions and Inflamability, and becaue Spirit and Sulphur are too Volatile, it fixeth them by its embracing them; that this Principle is in the Blood is manifet by its Guto; when the aline Particles in the Blood, are not enough exalted, by reaon of a bad Digetion, but remain crude, and for the mot part fixt, the Blood hence becomes thick and unable to perform its due circulation; o that
from hence arie Obtructions in the Bowels and olid parts, and hence Serous Crudities are abundandantly generated; but if by reaon of the Deficience and Depreion of the Spirit, the Salt be too much exalted and reduced to a fluor, a harp autere Diatheis doth then accot the Blood, uch as is oberved in Scorbutic Perons, and in thoe that are attended with Quartian Agues.

Phlegm or Water, which is the Vehicle of Sulphur and Spirit, and the Medium to unite them together with the Salt; for the other Principles being diolved, or at leat diluted in this, are kept in motion, but without it they become tiff and congealed; it is upon this Principle that the Fluidity of the blood depends; hereby alo its Conflagration and Adution is retrained and its Heat tempered.
Earth, is that which gives Conitency and Magnitude to Bodies, by this the too great Volatilization of the Blood and its Accenion is hindered.

Now tho thee Principles are
thoe whereof the Mas of Blood be compoed, yet this doth not at all detroy our former Aertion of the four Humours; for while the Blood is circulating in its containing Veels, ome of its Parts do continually wax old, and new ones do upply their Deficience; hence, either by Crudity, or too much Concoction, omething of neceity mut become ueles and Excrementicious, which by the Fermentation and Effervecence of the Blood (as in the Effervecence and Depuration of Wine) it is ecerned and eperated from its Mas: Thus that watery Humour that is percolated in the Cavities of the Stomach and Intetines, is called Phlegm; thoe Particles of Salt and Sulphur, and and ome other adut ones ecerned in the Liver, and received by the Vaa Choledocha, is that which they call Bile or Choler; and the Earthy Feculencies, ometimes in the Spleen, is that we call Melancholy. But thee things I hall more fully handle in the ubequent Chapter, where I hall Dicover omething
of the Depuration of the Blood.
