div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Functions of the Body.
div.p:
NOt to tread in the footteps of the Ancients farther than their Sentiments are agreeable to the Canons of Reaon and Experience, I hall not here confine my elf to proceed in their Method, it being incluive of ome particulars, altogether ridiculous and exploded by all the ingenious; for whoever will o devote himelf to all their Tenents, mut of neceity retrain his mind from believing not only Maxims of undeniable Verity, but alo demontrations of infallible Experience: Thus thoe that conform their Opinion to theirs, about the Subdiviion of the Nutritive Faculty into the Attractive, Retentive, Concoctive and Expulive, mut necearily thwart their own Experience,
at leat nullifie the contant Rules of Nature, in imagining new and fictitious ones; viz. By the attractive Faculty they would have us conceive that in the parts of this Body there is reident ome charming Vertue, whereby the Proxime Aliment is allured to them, or that they by a kind of Magnetic Influence, do effectually draw unto them the adjacent Nourihment.

By the Retentive they would have us believe that the parts of the Body finding this Aliment o agreeable and conimular to their Nature, are o inamour'd with them, as to retain them by voluntary Embraces.

The Genuine Ditribution of the Functions.The Genuine therefore and Legitime Ditribution of the Functions are into thee even, viz. The Nutritive, the Vital, the Senitive, the Locomotive, the Enunciative, and the Generative.

The Nutritive Function.Firt the Nutritive Function, foramuch as Animals can perform thoe Actions which their Nature is capable of, while they continue
in that tate in which they were firt formed; the God of Nature hath ordered that a Nutrition hould ucceed, which might dilate and amplifie their lender Fibres by interweaving and aimulating o many more congeners to them as might reduce their Bodies to a convenient magnitude, beides, which is a great end apired after by Nature in this neceary Function; this greatly conduceth and almot olely erves for the Conervation of the Animals, for ince the primary Principle of Life in every Animal, is a certain vital Flame and indegenary Heat (uch as is the rectified Spirit of Wine upon Acention) which penetrates and briskly agitates the fluid parts, continually feeding upon them, as its proper Pabulum or Fuel, which Sulphureous and Oily Particles afford Aliment to that lamp of Life; this < in non-Latin alphabet > or innate Heat at firt kindled by the Vegetative Soul, or rather the Platic Spirit in the Blood, contantly burning in the Heart, as in its Fountain or Primary
Focus, and thence by Diffuion of it elf thro the Arteries, warming, enlivening, and cherihing the Parts, would oon conume and diipate all its oluble Particles, had it not a contant upply and continual Reparation or Renovation of thoe decays it caues to exhale and evaporate by a ubtitution and aimulation of equivalent Particles in the room of thoe dipered and abum'd; and o at lat a Maramus or Conumption would immediately enue, and the fluid parts being quite exhauted or dipered, and the vital Flame being quite detitute and devoid of Sutenance, Life would totally be extinguiht, but to anticipate uch ad Effects and that this Principle of Life might not become our intern mortal Enemy o oon to detroy us; our Mother Nature hath contituted this noble Function,How Nutrition is performed. which, how it is performed, is now incumbent upon me a little to explicate; and that this may be done in a regular procedure, we mut ubdivide the Nutritive Faculty into
its three Branches, Chylification, Sanguification and Membrification or Aimulation, that o we may the better undertand the Procees of Nature in thee Operations.

Chylification the firt branch of this Function, called the firt Concoction, how it is done. Firt we mut enquire into the method of Chylification: This, which is the firt Concoction, is thus performed. When the Food is ufficiently chewed in the Mouth, by the Dentes molares, thoe Grinders appointed by Nature for Matication, it is detruded into the Ventricle or Stomach (for Deglution is made by Detruion) wherewith the Stomach being repleniht (the Appetite being atiate) it doth dilate it elf; and being alo endued with a power of Contracting its Membranous Tunicles, according to the proportion of the Food received, it doth cloely and trictly embrace the ame on all ides, and then hut both its upper and lower Orifice; the upper, that Vapours may not acend to the Brains, and that Concoctions might be more perfect; the lower let any of the
Meat hould decend into the Guts before it be converted into perfect Chyle: The Meat thus received into and embraced by the Stomach, is by and by moitened and diluted, partly by the drink received with it, and partly by an Acid Humour, the Relicts of the lat Concoction; which being endued with an Inciive Penetrating and Diolving Faculty, doth as it were cut and diolve the Solid Meat into very mall pieces, and like an excellent Mentruum, extracts a Tincture from its more Laudible and Alimentary Parts: This Mixture being advanced, que ad Minima, to the leat Particles, there preently ucceeds a Fermentation, whereby at lat the whole Mixture is brought to a new Conitence and Colour, not much unlike the Cream of Barley, and is that which Phyicians call the Chyle. The Chyle being thus perfectly concocted, is by the Gradual Contraction of the Stomach, detruded into the Guts; where the Guts by a Peri • alti •
Motion contracting them downwards; and this paing by the Intetines, its more pure and defecate parts are ditributed thro the Milky Veins, and the excrementitious and unprofitable parts are excluded by Stool: Thee Lactean Veins, carry the Chyle into the Common Receptacle called Receptaculum Commune, and from hence it is tranmitted thro the Ductus Thoracici, to the Subilavian Branches of the Vena Cava near the extern Jugular Veins; their being mixed with the Blood, it is by the Acendent Ttrunk of the Vena Cava, oon imported into the right Ventricle of the Heart.

Sanguification, or the Second Concoction.The next Branch of the Nutritive Function, is that of Sanguification; it is in this Concoction that the Chyle receiving yet farther Exaltations by a greater Solution of the more Noble and active Principles, once again depoites its old Color and Conitence, and o at length becomes perfectly changed into that true Liquor,How Chyle is tranmuted into Blood. which is called Blood; for as oon as the Vena Cava hath committed
the Matter of Nourihment into the right Ventricle of the Heart, the Ferment therein contained, working uddenly and throly upon it ets the Active Principles at a great freedom, and o inducing a new motion and effervecence into the Blood, doth happily impregnate it with Vitality; hereby its Nature is exalted, and thoe Natural Spirits contained in it are advanced into Vital or more Sublime and Active ones; while the Vital Spirits pre-exitent in the Ventricle of the Heart, do enkindle the ame Heat, and caue the ame diffuive or expanive motion in the Natural, which they themelves have formerly acquired. As for the Primary Agent or Efficient occupied in the Office of Sanguification, it is not the Liver, as Galen and his Sectators fictitiouly conceived; nor the Veins, as ome Anatomits have dream'd; nor truly the Heart, as Aritotle and his Diciples, with everal late Judicious Writers, have aerted; but by the Vital Heat reiding in the Blood: for the Heart
borrows all its Activity meerly from the Vital Blood contained in its Ventricles,The true Intrument that Nature makes ue of in makeing Blood. and ditributed into them by the Coronary Arteries; of which Vital Influx were the Heart deprived ome few moments, It would urceae its Activity and deit from its Sanguifying Function; yea it would become as Torpid and Motionles as any other part of the whole Body: o far is it from exalting the Chyle into o Noble a Nectar as the Blood is by any Simular Action of its own. Yet we mut acknowledge the Heart to be the Center and Chief Place of Reidence for this Vital Flame, and may notwithtanding be till properly tyled the Fountain of Life. As the Chyle in the firt Concoction was eperated from its Faeces, o in this econd Concoction the Crimon Juice is depurated from its unprofitable Excrementitious Parts; for the blood being an Heterogeneous Subtance, coniting of everal different Principles, when thoe Parts which are mot prone to Volatility, are diipated and conumed,
and when the Sweet and Inflamable Spirits are exhauted, certainly the remaining Mas mut needs become ueles and incommodious to Nature, and o degenerating into Excrements, ought as oon as may be to be equetred from the Pure Mas of Blood; • which wholeome Liquor thoe Excrementitious Parts are no longer deemed fit to remain Ingredients.

The Excrements ecerned from the Blood.The Excrements that are eperated from the Blood, are Choler, Phlegm, and Melancholy; to which we may add or under thee compehend Urine, Sweat, Tears, and the Lymphatic Liquor.

Choler is a bitter Excrement, generated of the Saline and Sulphureous Parts of the Blood, exalted by Adution, and eperated from the Blood thro the Parenchyma of the Liver by a kind of Percolation, and thence conveyed by its proper Veels into the Intetines, there rendring the Excrement of the firt Concoction fluxile; being excluded with them. This Bilious Excrement
is alo in a mall quantity effued out of the Capillary Arteries and collected in the Meatus Auditorius, or Cavity of the Ears, and there appears under the Form of that thick, yellow, and bitter Excrement we call Ear-wax.

Phlegm is a Cold and Moit Excrement, as for its Sapor it is ometimes Salt, omtimes Sweet, and ometimes Acid; to which we may add its Inipidnes as another; and as for its Conitence it is ometimes thin and erous, ometimes thick vicid and mucilaginous; and then it is called Glay Phlegm; and when it putrifies and corrodes, it becomes Salt and Eruginous; it is eperated from the Blood while it is wrought thro the Branches of the Celiacal Arterie terminated in the Stomach, and there by Tranudation immitted into the Cavity of it; where it is found endowed with ome Acidity: It is alo pewed forth out of the Meenteric Arteries into the Subtance of the Guts, and tranmitted into their Cavity by inenible paages; here it is inipid,
without any Tate at all. It alo ditils from the Brain, being excern'd from the Blood either by the Palate or Notrils; likwie it falls from the Pituitary Glandules ituate about the Bais of the Brain, and is alo eperated by the Glandulae Sublinguales and other Spongy Parts of the Jaws and Mouth, and o becomes Spittle.

Melancholy is a Cold and Dry Sediment of the Blood, in colour Black, in Tate owre and har • eperated by the Parenchyma of the Spleen; for the Blood brought hither by the Celiacal Arterie, and paing thro many turnings and windings, and as it were percolating thro the Parenchyma, doth leave behind ome alt and earthy parts, which after they have undergone ome alteration by their mutual Action one upon another, by their attrition and jutling in their paages thro the everal Cells, Cavities and Pores of the Parenchyma, are by the freh Blood which continually flows thither by perpetual Circulation carried back thro
the Veins into the Mas of Blood, in which they erve for a mot ueful and effectual Ferment; and whatoever of this Acid Humour is unfit to ferment the Mas of Blood, it is ent out and dicharged with the Serum by Urine; and tho this Hypotheis of the Spleen, being the Receptacle of Melancholy, be by many Anatomits exploded, yet Bartholine, Waleus, and Highmore, do till aert it: viz. That as the Liver doth ecern the Bile, o likewie the Spleen doth eperate a certain Acid Liquor from the Blood, which may be called Melancholy.

When this Ferment once grows too Sharp and Acid,The true Rice and Origin of Splenetic and Hypochondriac Affects. and acquires parts apt to provoke, irritate, and prick the enible parts of the Body, and the Fixed Salt becomes Fluid, it preently infects the whole tream of Blood, puts it into violent and diorderly Motions, vellicates the Nervous Parts, fixes the Spirits, puts all the Humours into trange confuion, and makes them apt to congeal and tagnate; and hence thoe Hypochondraic Affects
which uually molet Melancholy Perons have their Rice and Origin; for in thoe that labour under thee Ditempers, all the Fixed Salts of the Blood which circulate thro the Spleen, are there made Fluid, and at length come to prevail over the other Principles of the Blood, and turn the whole tock of it into a Liquor as harp as Vinegar or Spirit of Vitriol; by which means all the Spirits are depreed and kept under: Sowre Belchings and Vomitings enue, violent and irregular Motions and boyling Ebullitions of the Blood; which direful Maladies are oonet cured by thoe Medicines, which abounding with Fixed Salts, do precipitate the Blood; as thoe extracted from Steel, Tartar, Vitriol, and all Tetacious Bodies, as likewie Diuretic Remedies; for we find by experience that thee Medicines do weeten all harp Liquors and abate their pungency; for the Acrimony of Salt is not blunted by Sulphureous but Saline Bodies, by reaon that Fixed Salts by an intimate and cloe Union to
the Fluid do obtund their points and edges; thus the corroding harpnes of the Spirit of Vitriol is taken away by Salt of Tartar or Wormood; and aith Foneca, Salt of Tartar hath a great power in allaying the turbulent Acrimony of Melancholic Humours; for by an intrinic property in attracts all their harpnes: Thus if we ditil an Ounce of Tartar with two quarts of the tronget Vinegar, a Water will arie without any Acidity. And truly it is very probable that the reaon why Melancholy Perons find o much benefit from Medicines of Tartar, is that by weetning the Blood and Juice in the ame manner as that dulcifies Vineger; the Tartar frees the Body from thoe inconveniences which are caued by their pungency and acrimony; The way and manner how the Blood doth degenerate from a weet and balamic Contitution into a Liquor altogether harp, harh, and unpleaant; and how this alteration is effected, ought a little to be enquired into. As long as the
mall paages in the Spleen remain free and open, and the Subtance or Parenchyma of it is not grown o hard and earthy as to alter the Natural Poition and Shape of the Pores, the upply of a well prepared Ferment is duly and regularly performed; but if either from a Natural or Melancholic Contitution, or Errors in Diet, the Subtance of the Spleen be render'd too compact and olid, and the Pores and Spaces are altered from their Natural Figure and Magnitude, the Saline Particles in their percolation thro the Spleen, are o worn and grinded, that they are not only eperated from the Sulphur and Phlegm which is neceary for the making of a Ferment, but likewie forcibly disjoyned from the Earthy Principle, without which they cannot remain fixt, but preently become fluid; and then intead of a Ferment which hould maintain in the Blood an orderly and moderate Ebullition, a harp, eager, and pungent Liquor is ent into the Blood, which puts in into
irregular and tumultuous Fermentations, and renders the whole Frame and Crais of the Body diorderly. If we conult the Symptoms of Hypochondriac Perons, firt their Appetite to Meat, by reaon of the harpnes of the Ferment in the Stomach, is often too extravagant; yet the Meat is ill digeted, and much of it turned into owre Water; and hence the Stomach being provoked and convelled by the gnawing Acidity of its Mentruum, thee perons are troubled with continual Spitting, ometimes loathing and vomiting; they are uually Cotive, and their Faeces very black, by reaon of the Vitriolic Acidity which produces that Colour: their Urine is generally high-colour'd, like a trong Lie, becaue the Salt not being ufficiently volatilized and breathed out thro the Pores, is ent down in the Serum, thro the Urinary Paages: they find alo about their Breat a great Oppreion, Straitnes, and Difficulty of Breathing, and ometimes fall into Atmatic Paroxims:
Moreover, They complain of a great trembling and palpitation of the Heart, of a great weight and oppreion of it; which Symptoms proceed partly from the harpnes of the Nervous Juice, which grate • and vellicates the Nerves, and is apt to tagnate in them, and partly from the Blood, which is not well and regularly fixed in the Heart; hence proceed acute and wandring Pains about the Mediatinum and Shoulders, and ometimes uch as imitate the Cholic and Nephritic Paions.

Thus tho this Acid Juice, according to Helmont and Sylvius, may be very ueful in ome parts of the Body, and tho it may erve for a ueful Ferment, yet too great a quantity of it in the Blood, may caue a Dieae and indicate an Evacuation; but it is now high time for me to return from this Digreion.

Aimulation, Membrification, or the third Concoction.We come now to the third Concoction, which is the third Office in the Nutritive Function, and that is Membrification or Aimulation;
this is performed when the Nutritive Juice is ufficiently prepared, and by the Impule of the conveying Veels is brought near to the parts that are to be nourihed, and there by an Appoition • , Agglutination, and Tranmutation, all which mut in order ucceed each other, is united to them. The Material or Contitutive Principle of this is now commonly reputed not to be the Blood (tho Aritotle greatly contended for it, and the School of Phyicians hath given its Suffrage to verify this Tenent) but a certain weet, mild, and balamic Liquor, analogous to the White of an Egg, out which a Chicken is formed.

The next is the Vital Function;The Vital Function. this is that whereby Vital Spirits are generated in the Heart for the Conervation of Life in the whole Body: Life primarily coniting in the procreation of Heat and Spirits, and their due Contemperations with the Blood and Members of the Body, and hereby vivifying them, it is mot neceary a living Body hould be furnihed with them; and
eeing that they are diipable and oon ready to be pent, the Body would oon be left in a tate altogether inactive and liveles, were it not upplied by a continual Generation of Vital Spirits. By Vital Spirits I mean nothing ele but the more fine,What Vital Spirits are. volatile, aetherial, ublim'd and ubtiliz'd part of the Blood; by which the Fermentation and Intern Motion of the Particles in that Liquor is maintained, and that in its Circular Motion preerved from Stagnation and Coagulation; and when the Body remains in a tate of Health a eperation is continually made of all Immicible and Heterogeneous Bodies, which are either taken in with the Aliment, or ele come in the Blood from the Ambient.The Archeus of the Peudochymits a meer Fiction. This is that Vital Flame I before mentioned, and it is nothing ele that the Peudochymits do undertand by that great Term, their Noble Archeus, that Vox & praeterea Nihil.

To the Conervation of this Lamp of Life, or the Generation of Vital Spirits, there are two Actions or
Motions ubervient, viz. Pulation and Repiration.

Pulation how performed. Pulation is not made a Motive Faculty inherent in the Blood, either in repect of its Ebullition and Rarefaction, or Vection and Attraction, but partly by the Influx of the Blood ditending the Ventricles of the Heart, and partly by that pulific Faculty reiding in that Fountain of Life; this Pulation conits of three parts, the Sytole, the Diatole, and the Periytole, or intermediate ret.

The Sytole is the Contraction of the Heart to a narrower compas, expelling the Blood contained in the right Ventricle thro the Vena Arterioa into the Lungs, and that contained in the left into the great Arterie; and o into all the parts of the Body. Hence we may ee the reaon why the Motion of the Heart is mot enibly perceived on the left ide, without imagining the Heart to be more ituate on that ide than on the other.

The Diatole is a Dilatation of the Heart to receive the Blood in the
right Ventricle out of the Vena Cava, and into the left out of the Arteria Venoa.
The Periytole is a certain quiet or hort ret between the Sytole and Diatole; but of this ee more pag. 108.
Repiration its two parts, Inpiration and Expiration. Repiration is an Act of the Lungs and Thorax, coniting of two contrary Motions, alternately ucceive, Inpiration and Expiration.
Inpiration is caued by the Dilatation of the Lungs and Breat, that o the Ambient Air might be received.
Expiration is the Contraction or Compreion of thoe Parts, whereby the ame Air is expelled; jut as the Air is received in and expelled by a pair of Bellows.

The ue of Repiration is not as hath been vulgarly held by the Ancients, to refrigerate or cool the heat of the Heart, for we ee Air blown out of a pair of Bellows, doth not any way extinguih, but promote the accenion of Fire; but the ue of Repiration is as Dr. Charleton aith,
1.The ue of Repiration in Eight particulars. To ubtilize the Blood, and by the admition of Air make it more convenient Fuel for the Lamp of Life and matter of Vital Flame.
2. Or as Dr. Henhaw ingeniouly uppoeth, To perform the Office of a Tonic Motion, which is wanting in the Lungs: for aith he, In all the Muculary Parts of the Body, there is a Natural Contraction of the Fibres, whereby the Blood proceeding from the Heart, and diffuing it elf thro thee parts, is expelled thence, and caued to recede to its Fountain again; now the Lungs being a lax, pongy, and Parenchymous part, is devoid of this Motion, and certainly did not Repiration upply its defect, it would oon be overwhelmed with the redundancy of Blood coming upon them, and o a Suffocation of the Animal would immediately enue.
3. It erves for the Creation of Voice, whether Articulate or Inarticulate.
4 For the ditribution of Chyle, both out of the Stomach and Guts,
thro the Venae Lactea into the grand Receptacle, and out of that Receptacle into the Ductus Chyliferi.
5. For the Excluion of Excrements.
6. For Smelling.
7. For Coughing, Sternutation, Excretion, and Emunction.
8. To ait the Body in any trange violent Motion.

The Senitive Function.The next is the Senitive Function; this is that whereby a Man doth exercie his Sene: Whether or no Sene be performed by the Influx of Animal Spirits, I cannot here determine, there being o many, almot inextricable difficulties on both ides. The Senes are commonly known to be five,The number of the Senes. The Viive, Auditive, Tactive, Gutive, and Olfactive, or Seeing, Hearing, Touching, Tating, and Smelling; each of which Senes have their proper Organs. In every Senation there are thee four things requiite:What things are requiite in every Senation. Firt, An Intrument well dipoed. Secondly, A proportionate Object. Thirdly, An adapted Medium. Fourthly, A convenient ditance
between the Object and the Intrument.

The Loco-motive Function.The next Function in order, is the Loco-motive, whereby a Man performs local and voluntary Motion; the Intruments that Nature hath upplied a Humane Body with for the performance of this are Mucles, Tendons, Ligaments, and the Junctures of the Bones.

The Enunciative Function.The Enunciative is that Function whereby a Man exprees the Sentiments of his Mind by his Voice; the Organs of this Function are the Lungs, the Apera Arteria, the Mouth: that the Voice might be at pleaure, either intended or remitted the Tube of this Arterie is furnihed with Ringy Cartilages, the lower of which, if when contracted, the attracted Air doth meet,How a trong and a weak Voice is caued. there is intantly caued a trong percuion: and hence a great Voice reults, but by the uppermot a maller re-percuion is made. And hence an acute and queeking Voice arieth; and that the ound after it is modelled in the Larynx might be articulated, Nature hath given us
a Throat, Tongue, Lips, Teeth, and Notrils.

The Generative Function.The lat of all the Functions is the Generative, this was appointed for the multiplying of Mankind; it is from the mutual Congres of two Sexes, the prolific Seed, being emitted from both, and treaured up in the Magazine of the Females Womb, that the firt Rudiments of a tender Foetus do emerge. There being abundance of Natures Curioity under this Head, I hall take occaion a little to amplifie hereupon, and hall treat of,
1. The Nature and Origin of the Seed.
2. The Manner and Signs of Conception.
3. The Formation of the Child in the Womb, and its Poition.
4. The Manner of its Exit or Coming forth.

The Nature and Origin of Seed.The Seed is a Humid and Spirituous Subtance, elaborated in the Teticles from the reidue of the third Concoction, or from the Arterial Blood, having a prolific Vertue
and concurring to the procreating of the Foetus, not only Virtually but alo Materially.

The Efficient caue of Spermification is the Parenchyma of the Teticles; thee by their hot and moit Temperature, and alo an Intrinic Specific Propriety, doth convert the Arterial Blood into Sperm, which after it is here prepared, is reconded in the Seminary Veels; and if there be a redundancy, that which abounds is either carried back thro the Spermatic Veins to the Heart, or goes to the Nutrition of the Teticles, or ele is excern'd thro the Lymphaducts; for without the Teticles Seed is not, unles extraordinarily, generated; for it is from them that the Seed receives both its Form and Colour; and if a Conception happen from one that is catrated, it is by reaon of ome Seed before the Amputation of them, prepared and reconded. Women alo do emit Seed, and have likewie for that purpoe Teticles given them by Nature. In the Seed there are two parts,
The Spirituous part, and the Colliquament. The Spirituous Part is that which caueth in the Seed a Turgency and Frothines, by reaon of the extream Mobility and Volability of the Spirits. The Cras Colliquament is that moit and watery Subtance which manifetly appears when the Spirits vanih and evaporate; for it then lays down its Whitenes and Spumoity.

This fruitful Liquor by its prolific Vertue, after the Spermatic Contact in Coition, doth o affect the terus of the Female, as to impregnate it with Fecundity, and make it alo become Prolific; which having received this Platic Generative Power, communicated to it from the Male, doth put this Power into exercie, and o procreateth its own like; and truly the Vertue proceeding from the Male, doth o largely fructifie the whole Female, that it produceth a thoro Change and Alteration, as well in the Frame of their Minds, as Contitution of their Bodies.

2. The Manner and Signs of Conception:Conception the Manner of it. The terus of the Female, by the previous Convere he hath had with the Male, and his Incitements which he ueth to entice her, as alo by Natures own Inclination and Tendency, is adapted for Conception; which preparaion of the terus conits in this:

Firt, The terus appears thicker and more flehy, and afterwards in the interior Superfice, which is the place where the future Conception is to be received, groweth more tender, anwering in Lubricity and tendernes the intern Ventricles of the Brain: in ome places it hath little Knobs, which do well inward and become exceeding oft; the terus thus reduced to a tate of Maturity, and Coition immediately ucceeding; the Seeds of both Sexes being effued at the ame time, the Males into the Neck of the terus, and th • Females into the Cavity of her own Matrix, the Womb being endued with the property of attracting and drawing to it elf the Virile Seed, it greedily
ucks it in, and there the Seed of both Sexes being exactly mixt together and trictly contained within the Confines of the terus, the whole Body of the Womb doth contract it elf, and the intern Orifice of it becomes o cloely hut, that the Point of the harpet Needle cannot be admitted; the two orts of Seed there reconded are cherihed by the Heat of the terus, and thereby their Heat and Spirit tirred up, and the Platic Vertue, which before lay Dormant there, is now reduced into Act, and hence immediately Conception enues. The Signs of which are thee:
Seven Manifet Signs of Conception.1. A kind of horror and trembling after Coition, which is caued by the Contraction and drawing together the Womb.
2. Retention of the Seed, If the Seed fall not out again we may Conjecture there is Conception.
3. A cloe Occluion of the Orifice of the terus.
4. A Suppreion of the Natural Coures.
5. A Swelling, Hardnes, and Pain in the Breat.
6. A Languid Appetite and Deire of Venery.
7. A Naueating and Loathing of Meat.

3. The Manner of the Formation of the Foetus and its Poition in the Womb. The Efformative Vertue being now excited by the Heat of the Womb, doth wrap up the whole Seminal Matter into two Membranes or Tunics, the one is called Chorion and the other Amnios, and in even days time after the Conception the Lineaments of the Spermatic Parts begin to appear; for if a Geniture after the eventh day uffer an untimely Exit, and be cat into Water, there will appear in it three little Bubbles, which are the Rudiments of the three Principal Parts, and abundance of little Filaments, which are the Threds of the other Spermatic Parts. All the Spermatic Parts are perfected in Males in the pace of Thirty Days, in Females in Forty; the flehy Parts in Males are perfect in Three Months, in Females in Four, and then the Foetus begins to be
quick. The Spermatic Parts are generated of the Seed of both Sexes, but the Flehy Parts of Mentruous Blood, which hath an Influx thither till the whole Structure of the Foetus is compleated.

The Poition and Situation of the Infant in the Womb.The Situation or Poition of the Infant in the Womb, is commonly found to be thus; His Knees drawn up to his Belly, his Thighs bent backward; his Feet hanging down, his Hands elevated to his Head, whereof one is placed about his Temples or Ears, the other upon his Cheeks; in which Parts there are white pots dicovered in his Skin; as Signs of Confrication; his Spine or Back-bone bent-round and his Neck being inflected, his Head hangs near his Knees; the Embryo is ituated with that Poition of Parts wherewith we commonly apply our elves to ret, with his Head uppermot, and his Face directed towards his Mothers Spine; but a little before his Birth, his Head being bent downwards, he dives towards the Bottom and Orifice of the Matrix, as if he were eeking his way out.

Latly,The Manner of its Birth.The Manner of its Exit or Birth: After the Foetus hath acquired its due Conformation, Nutrition, and Augmentation, not finding a ufficient Aliment, and wanting Air to Ventilate the abounding Heat, begins to eek a larger Space; and being irritated, ditends the Membranes of the
terus: and endeavours to extricate himelf out of that Prion, wherein he is o confined and incarcerated; and hence reults a double Motion, one of the Foetus triving to get out, and another of the terus it elf endeavouring to exclude the Foetus: All things being thus arrived to a Mature State, and the Matrix being near Delivery, doth bear down, groweth oft, and openeth its Orifice; the Waters alo, as they commonly call them, are gathered, that is a certain part of the Chorion, in which the aforeaid Humour is contained, doth uher in the Foetus, and lide down from the Matrix into the Vagina or Sheath of the Womb; and the Neighbouring Parts alo are
looened and ready to ditend, and the Articulation of the Os Sacrum, and the Share-bone to the Hanch-bone (which Articulation is by Synchondrois or a grily Ligament) is o oftened and looened that the aforeaid Bones do eaily give way to the parting Infant; and by gaping open, do amplifie the whole Region of the Hypogatrium or lower Belly: and when thee things are in this condition, it is certain the time of Birth is at hand. As for the time when the Birth happens,In what Month the Birth commonly happens. altho it be regular in almot all other Animals, yet in Women it is very enormous; for ometimes it happens in the Seventh Month, ometimes in the Ninth, ometimes in the Tenth or Eleventh, eldom in the Eighth; if it does, the Infant eldom lives: the Caue of which Atrologers attribute to the unhappy Influx of Saturn, which they ay rules on the Eighth Month. The ordinary Computation of going with-Child oberveth that time which our Bleed Saviour, the Perfectet of all Men did fulfil in the Virgins Womb;
namely from the Day of Annunciation, which is in March, to the Bleed day of His Nativity, which is celebrated in December; and according to this Rule the Sager Matrons, keeping their Account (while they cat in the wonted day in every Month wherein they were accutomed to have their Purgations) they are eldom out of their Reckoning; but Ten Revolutions of the Moon being expired, they are delivered, and reap the fruit of their Womb upon that very day; whereon were it not for their Pregnation their Purgations would enue.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the Sexes.
div.p:
NAture (or rather the God of Nature) after the large and tately Theatre of this World was erected and perfectly finihed, began to contemplate what kind of Creatures
might be bet adapted to Act upon this lower tage, and therefore Man being a Creature endued with Reaon, was choen to be the Chiefet Actor; and that the Comedy might be carried on with more Variety. Nature the Dipoer of it, thought it requiite that the Perons whom he would caue to Act their everal ditinct and different Parts in various Scenes and everal Circumtances, might be dicriminated one from another, not only by the difference of their magnitudes, complexions, ages, or phyiognomies, but alo of their exes; and that they might not only be inveted with different Apparel, but that their Souls might be Cloathed with Bodies of different compoures: Thus She hath contrived that the Spectators might be pleaed with the Varieties of Men and Women, and that the Rules of Oeconomics in viible practice and the Actions of Lovers might be the better repreented in their proper Scenes. Here may be een how the Diligent Houe-wife is buie in her Dometic Affairs, while her Careful Husband is edullous
abroad, in getting a upply. Here alo in another Scene we may behold how the Amorous Glances of an Atracting Beauty do Captivate the Affections of the Nobler Sex, how a doteing Lover Courts his Mitris, while She at firt requites him with nothing but Coynes and Avernes; but at lat being overcome with the retles and unwearied Expreions of his Love, he breaks forth into a career of Love, and profeeth he hath won her Affections and elevated her Mind into uch a paion, that it is now impoible for her to retrain from breaking forth into the mot ardent Raptures and pathetic Expreions of an undoubted Love; now her former pretended Coynes is turned into amorous Embraces, and her wonted eeming Avernes to the Carees of entire Amity; and modet Kies become Badges to dicover thoe flames of pure Love, which he couched under the urface of an incened Breat. Strangenes is now turned into Familiarity, mall Acquaintance into Conjugal Society,
and former Separation into a cloe Union of two Minds, and a mutual Enioyment one of another.

The Ditinction of Man into two Sexes.It being our buines to conider Man in all manner of uch like circumtances, we hall here take occaion to exantlate omething concerning the Sexes appropriated to Mankind, and they are generally known under the Names of Male and Female.

The Male his Nature and Difference from the Female.The Male (on whoe Maculine Soul Nature hath conferred a Body in Strength and Vigor almot adequate to it) is of a hotter and drier Temperature than the Female; for if we can give credence to our common Anatomits,Whena Male and when a Female is generated. the Seed whereof the Male is generated, is of a hotter Nature than that whereof the Female; becaue, ay they, it decends out of the right Side from the Trunc of the Vena Cava, while that which affords Matter for Generation of the Female, proceeds out of the left Side from a branch of the Emulgent.

Their Native Heat invigorating their Bodies, makes them robut
and more fit for Labour, and gives them a vehement Pule and Repiration, and caues in them a trong and Man like Voice, exhales and dries up the relicts of Humidity, which Nature cannot dipoe of for Nutrition, and leaves nothing at all uperfluous; and hence the abundance of Vapours, which this inulting Heat caueth to be emitted thro the Pores of the Body, ome of them there at their very Exit thence are condened by the Extern Ambient Cold, and there remain in the Form of Hairs, for (which is very obervable) Nature hath given a Hair to every Pore, unles thoe which are contituted in thoe places, where by Attrition Mhey are continually worn off, • or their Generation impeded; hence it is that Men are more Hairy than Women, even in the whole Superfice of their Bodies, thee innate colorific Particles, do by their agitating Virtue, caue the Blood more briskly to ferment and circulate with more velocity; they amplifie the Veins and
other Veels, and make the whole Structure of the Mucles more compact and olid; as for the influence this hath on the Soul, or what different Operations it caueth in the Mental Faculties; we may only take notice that they of this Sex have a more profound judgment than thoe of the other, tho not o acute a Phanie; their Wills are more table and reolute, tho they are o full of Affection.

The Female.The Female (the Character of whoe generous Sex I know not how to delineate, leat by attempting it I hould too much derogate from their Worth and Excellency) is of a colder and moiter Contitution, yet of a more delicate and finer Contexture than the Male; yea, ome of this Sex, both in the Beauty and exquiite Contexture of their Bodies, and in the Pregnancy and Acutenes of their Phanie, do far excel any of the other.

When we conider how he who is the Sole Creator of all things (from the Center of whoe Munificence all His Creatures derive their beings)
hath diplayed the effulgent Rays of his Benevolence,The Praie and Encomium of that Noble Sex, both as to their Beauty and Phantaie. and manifeted the Replendent Beams of his Inimitable Work-man-hip, in making o Glorious a Creature as Man out of uch Corruptible Principles and uch Fading Elements; how can we but tand and admire Him? But when we take a view of ome of this Noble Sex, whoe Bodies He hath framed into o Beautiful Compoures, how can we but be atonih'd at uch products of His Efficience? Such lively Features and uch a Delicate Structure of Body is ometimes repreented to our Sight, as Charms the Affections of the mot Moroe and Rigorous Stoic, and where the Man is not byaed to the Admiration of the Creator, the very apect of this makes him indulge it to admire the Creature; yea ome are o mitten and atonihed at one glance, that they tand agat, and think that the Beauty of the Univere is therein Epitomized, and that the whole force of Natures Puiance did combine in the exertion of its Power for the production
of o Curious a Creature. But all this is but vanity which oon decayes, it is the other Excellency, often to be found in Women, that is far trancendent, and that is Phantaie; tho this often becomes too extravagant: The fine contexture of their Brain makes their Invention far more acute and pregnant, and its moiture adapts it to take impreion. How exceeding quick and ready are the wits of ome Women? How will they ometimes puzzle and non-plus the wits of Intelligent Men? And how Facetiouly will they write, epecially when their Phantaies are elevated with Love-Paions.

The Excellency of Marriage.Having conidered both the Sexes a-part, let us now conider them in that bleed Bond or Matrimonial Contract which God hath intituted to unite them. There is certainly in each of thee Sexes a very impetuous inclination given them by Nature to this Union, and this doubtles is as Natural to them as to have an Appetite to their
Food; nay, I do not quetion but the Function of Generation, is attended with no les Incitements to the exercie of it, than any other Function of the Body; yet uch is the depraved tate of Mankind, that till his Senual Appetites are almot inatiable, and his Carnal Deires boundles and irregular; not only in deiring abolutely forbidden Things, but alo in craving an immoderate meaure of thoe Things that God hath indulged him moderately to ue; and therefore God hath in his Infinite Widom thought it requiite to confine and limit every Man to his own Wife,1 Cor. 7.2. and every Woman to her own Husband; and that there is more Comfort and Felicity to be found in this Union, where there is a happy Congruity, none unles contradicting Reaon, Experience, or Natural Inclination, or thwarting the Laws of Nature and the Intitutions of the Divine Creator, can deny; and jutly may thoe perons be deemed Fools, who for ome mall pretended inconvenience of that Life, will
rahly and inconiderately hurry and precipitate themelves to the actual commiion of uch horrid Crimes as make Nature it elf ahamed and bluh with an angry regret, and invocate the plagues of an incened Deity; contemning the intituted Laws of Nature, and commiting Actions contrary to it.

Reflections on them that peak againt and calumniate Women.Others there are, who out of a Moroe and Currih Humour, do not only derogate from the Praie due to the Creator, but alo abue that whole Noble (tho Inferiour) Sex; univerally calumniating all Women, and uperciliouly inulting over their imperfections, when alas, thee pragmatic conceited perons, have either by their dogih and currih Tempers and devilih Pride, enraged themelves with a paion of Envy at the Love and Repect which is civilly paid them, by Men of a better Dipoition than they, or ele they are guilty of uch hellih Enormities, as divert their Affections from all Lawful Objects, cauing them inatiably
to purue thoe things that are wholly illegitimate, and prohibited by the Divine Legilator. Let none then, indulging in themelves that Squint-eyed Paion, contemn and depie the Intitutions of God and Nature; for certainly whooever o do, give great Supicion to the Intelligent World, that they ue unlawful means to uffocate their lawful and regular Affections. Some are grown o audacious and impudently wicked, as with a Brazen Fore-head, wholly abjuring the Rules of Chatity, and violating the Rules of Common Modety, confronting the face of many, and openly proteting there is nothing in the Marriage-bed, but what the Pleaures of Whorih Embraces do far urpas: But at lat,What befals them that abhorring Marriage, contaminate themelves with polluted Women. how are thee Men deluded, when their whole Bodies, infected with the Contagion of Whorih Carcaes, break out into Venereal Borches or Pocky Bubo's, are perplexed with Virulent Gonorrhea's moleted with Nocturnal Pains, and having their Throats or Noes exulcerated
by the corroding particles of a deperate Contagion communicated to the whole Mas of Blood; and this they receive as a mall inconiderable reward for their former brave Exploits, while on the other ide they are acrifiing their infected ouls to the Altars of Satan. Certainly then it is now evident that the Comforts and Pleaures that are to be enjoyed in a Married Condition, mut far trancend uch impure promicuous Congrees as wholly invert the etabliht Canons of Mother Nature: Yea truly, I verily believe that this State doth urpas a tireome Life of Solitude, neither would any other continual Society be o atisfactory, or in the leat parallel to it.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the Ages of Man.
div.p:
HAving curolarily ailed over the wide Seas of this Microcrom, both as to the Soul, and as to the Parts, Temperments, and Functions of the Body, and alo in repect of the difference of the Sexes: We come now to enter upon our lat, Voyage, which when we have finiht, we hall draw in our Lacerated Sails, and enter into our lat Port and Haven, where we hope to find a uccesful Harbour. Here then it is incumbent on us to decribe Man being a Creature not coniting of one Simple, Homogeneous, and Elementary Matter, but compoed of everal ditinct and omewhat contrary Principles, and that not in equal proportion, but one alwayes having predominance over
another, it cannot be expected he hould always continue in uch a State and Crais of Body as he was born with; for the Natural Heat making ue of the Primogenial Moiture, cannot but by degrees conume and wate it, it elf alo by its continual motion and the reluctancy of ome Principles hardly combutible, is very much debilitated and diminihed; hence the habit of Bodies is render'd fluxible, and Man paes in a hort time, as it were out of one Crais and Contitution of Body into another, o that the pace in which uch like mutations as thee are made, is properly termed an Age:
• iverius. Or the true Notion of an Age is that pace of Life, in which by the action of the Native Heat upon the Primogenial Moiture, the Contitution of the Body is manifetly changed.

The Diviion of the Ages of Man.The Ages of Man (not to divide them according to the Rules of Lawyers and Atrologers, but as is mot conitent to the Canons of Phyic, and mot redounds to the
ue of Phyicians) are Four; Pueritia, Childhood, Juventus, Youth, Conitens Aetas, Middle-Age; Senectus, Old-Age: Before I particularly handle each of thee, I will only take notice how Nature takes delight in her Quaternary changes. The Contitutions of Men are ditinguiht by Four Humours and Temperaments, every Dieae by its Four Parts, the Beginning, the Increment, the State, and the Declenion. A Year is divided by its four-fold Mutation into o many Quarters, and the Ages of Man neither exceed not fall hort of this number.

Pueritia, or Child-hood,Child-hood. is from the Birth (or very Exit of the Partus, from the confining Cubicle of its Mothers Womb, into the ample Pavilion of a capacious World) to the 25th year of its Age. This Age is, for the mot part, hot and moit; it is again ditributed into Four Parts, the firt is Infancy, which is extended to the Fourth, or according to others to the Seventh
Year. The Second Pueritia, trictly o called to the Fourteenth. The Third Pubertas to the Eighteenth. The Fourth Adolecentia, to the Twenty fifth.

The Character of an Infant.When the feeble Infant firt enters upon the Stage of this World, how exactly doth it act the Part of a bewildred tranger, and imitate ome wandring Pilgrim, arrived at ome trange and unknown Haven, or one that is banih'd out of a comfortable Region, where he could indulge himelf in what mot of all delighted him, into ome exotic and detitute Countrey; or like a Peron very well cloathed, who in an intant, he knows not how, is tript Naked, and o expoed to the Eyes of them whom he never aw before: Thus the Infant, after its excluion from the Womb, looks on this ide and on that ide, and in the mid't of Friends ees no Friend, and then by its Countenance eems to expres (or at leat it is legible in its Face) what Aritotle, when among his Friends,
vocally pronounced, < in non-Latin alphabet > , O Friends no Friend! and becaue it cannot expres its own Sentiments, or manifet its wants in the unknown Language of that trange Land, which it is now by force and compule reduced to inhabit, it begins to utter its Complaint in its own proper Tongue; and bewails its forlorn Condition with Ehu's; and uch like deplorable Interjections; but at lat finding a neceity of its abiding here, it endeavours to acquaint it elf with the Modes and Fahions of the place wherein it is, and to imitate their Cutoms and Practices; it is pleas'd with Toys and Baubles, and the Rattles of Infancy then arride it; and thus he pends the two former parts of his Age in Folly and Vanity, and truly the third little better; but when he arrives at the Fourth, which is Adolecentia, he divets himelf not only of the Swadling Cloaths of his Infancy, but alo of his Childhood Apparel, and then puts on his Manly Gown; he abjures the
Trifles he o long retained, and throws away all uch illy Buffoonries, and betakes himelf to thoe things that have more Solidity in them.

Youth his Character.The next Age to this is Youth, which is Hot, and omewhat Dryer than the Age before decribed; now the Heat becomes Vigorous and Intene, and precipitates the Blood adapted for Motion, into a more than ordinary Fermentation; it excites the Appetites to purue the things they deire with a trange kind of Impetuoity, and hurries them to atiate thoe Cravings and Concupicible Appetites. Now the Body is mot robut, and the vigorous Spirits are almot indefatigable; now Paions are on every ide ready to accot the Man, and ometimes the violent Impules, excited in his Body, make a great impreion on his united Mind, and caue uch a trange influence upon his Soul, that he finds it very difficult to abtract his Thoughts from thoe aaulting Repreentations injected
into his extravagant, or too inordinate Phantaie; and thus the Mind doth too often conent to thoe Peccaminoities, to which Youth is too much addicted: And hence it is very requiite and becoming Youth, for them to ue a Bridle to all thoe unruly Paions, that they fly not out into a career of thoe (whch they think Heroic) Pranks that their Juvenile Age is o inclinable unto; or o far trancend their Sphere or exceed their Limits, as to indulge themelves in uch Hellih Debaucheries, as always inhane a future hame.

I do not conclude but Paions are lawful, and where they are regular, none can malign them; the forbidden Object, or the undue meaure of the Paions themelves, is that which makes them inful; for uch is the Contexture of a Humane Body, and uch is the brisk fluctuating Motion of the Sanguine Liquor, that Man is always dipoed for one Paion or other. For when an Object obviouly
preented to the Mind, is apprehended by it to be of a Nature Evil and Noxious, the Soul is thereby preently timulated to the Paion of Hatred, and thence excited to an ireful Revenge; but when a pleaing and delectable Object is repreented, the Soul immediately carees it: Hence arieth the Paion of Love, the Body in the mean time finding a great Congruity between it elf and the object beloved, complies to embrace it; and thus it is alo in repect of the other paions of Youth. This Age continues to the thirty firt Year, ome will have it lat to the Fortieth.

The Conitent Age.The Third is Aetas Conitens, which begins where the other ends and continues to the Forty-fifth or Fiftieth Year, it is called the Conitent Age, becaue thoe that are in this age do eem to tay, top, continue, or conit in the ame tate; for tho the trength in this Age doth begin omething to be diminiht, yet this mutation is not evident or perceptible in the habit or actions of the Body. This Age is commonly cold
and dry, and hence more inclinable to Melancholy than any other.

Old Age.The lat is Senectus or Old-age, which continues to the very extremity of Life; this is ubdivided into three parts. Prima Senectus from the Fiftieth Year to the Sixtieth, Aetas Ingravecens from the Sixtieth Year to the Seventieth, and Decrepitude from the Seventieth Year to the end of Life. Now Man having pat thro the Spring of his Infancy, the Summer of his Youth, and the Autumn of his Middle-Age, bids Adieu to the pleaures of them all, and now hath nothing ele to enjoy but the hardhip of a harp and troubleome Winter; now Baldnes with a Ca
• ities of ome till adhering locks, is his Heads bet Ornament, and while he walks leaning on his Staffe he enibly experiences the latter part of Sphynx's Riddle. An univeral laitude now eizes the Members of his Body, and a thouand maladies accompany him to his Grave. Old-Age it elf is a compound dieae attended with numerous direful Symptomes as Cachexies, Imbecillities of
the Stomach, dejected Appetite, Obtructions, undue Concoctions of the Blood both as to its Serum, Bile and Melancholy, Contriction of the pores, Cotivenes, and a very tardy depoition and excluion of the foeces, Anxieties of the Mind, Nocturnal Inquietudes & Pains in the Head. Now the Nerves are contracted by painful Convulions, or on the contrary looened by Paralytic Affects, now the whole tone of the Parts is vitiated, Repiration impeded, and the fleh made arid. He is now perplexed with a continual Catarrh, and the perpetual ditillation of Phlegm upon his Lungs, caueth a difficulty of breathing; alo by reaon of the exiccation of the Apera Arteria and induration of the Cartilages of the Larynx there is caued either a total abolition or at leat a depravation or diminution of the voice; in fine all manner of loathom Dieaes are here accumulated, and the whole Gang of cruciating dolors are here in concatinated: For
Febre caret Sola, circumilit agmine facto
Morborum omne genus.
There is carce any Infirmity incident to Man except a Feaver that is not predominant in Old-Age, he is beet and urrounded with a troop of Dieaes when he is altogether unable to reit a ingle one.

The Concluion.Thus Man having lived out this Age alo, at lat dies and becomes a victime to his lat, but Fatal Enemy. Now his Pule is topt, and that which Phyicians call Facies Hypocratica is Excellenty Delineated in his Countenance; he now reigns himelf up a Captive to Death, and acknowledgeth him the Conquet.

Thus we have in a very hort Dicoure concluded the whole Decription of Man, both as to his Spiritual and Corporeal Part, as to his Contitutions and Sexes, and likewie from Head to Foot, and from his firt Conception to his lat Diolution.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p:
WHEREAS part of the Noble Faculty of Phyic, coniteth in preerving the Health of Man, when preent, as well as retoring it when it is lot and wanting; the Author of the fore-going Dicoure hath thought fit to advertie thoe into whoe hand this mall Treatie may accidentally fall, that, to prevent thoe Maladies that oft times ineinbly accot the Body, he hath prepared mot excellent and effectual Tablets, of a very pleaant and grateful Tate; two or three of which being diolv'd in the Mouth, in a Morning, after the manner of Lozenges,
and fating an hour or two after, is an excellent Preervative of Health, expelling from the Body the caue of thoe Ditempers, which for want of due and timely care in uing uch Preervatives, do at lat o triumph over the Body, that the Force and Vertue of more Herculean and powerful Medicines can hardly uppres them. They reit all manner of Putrifaction, and are an effectual Antidote againt whatoever Contagion, they preerve the Lungs and free the Stomach and Intetines, from thoe Crudities that o often precipitate the whole Mas of Blood into uch violent Ebullitions and undue Fermentations, as either and in Agues, Feavers, or ome Acute Paroxims; or ele either extinguih the Native Heat and Vital Spirit, or caue to be exhaled the Natural & Primogenial Moiture, and o bring upon the whole Body a Combination
of uch Chronic Ditempers as are very difficult to be cured; which before, by uch a afe Medicament as this, might have eaily been prevented. They keep the Body oluble, and purge very gently, and prevent everal Indipoitions that proceed from Cotivenes; neither are they altogether Preervative, but likewie Retorative; for they are very good againt the Scurvey, Dropie, Jaundies, Griping of the Guts, Cachexy, or an ill Habit of Body, proceeding from undue Concoctions; they open all Obtructions of the Liver, Spleen, and Bowels, and remove Pains of the Heart, Head, and Stomach; in hort, they o rectifie, alter, and qualifie the whole Mas of Blood, that they exceedingly help Nature, in throwing off almot whatoever Morbific Matter oppreeth her, and may afely be ued in whatoever Maladies of the like Nature; one or two of them may alo be diolved in a Dih of Coffee or
Tea, and have the like Effects.

Cauing in the Blood, a proportionate Fermentation, and reducing it to its regular Circulation, opening Obtructions in thoe Parts which Nature hath detin'd and appointed to ecern and throw off the Excrements of the Blood, and o expelling thoe ueles and unprofitable Parts which Nature hath no longer deemed fit to remain Ingredients of that wholeome Liquor and Balom of Life: Hereby it takes away Pains
